DEBATE.TITLE: DEATH OF THE HONOURABLE REGINALD THOMAS POLLARD

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I draw attention to the announcement of the death of the Honourable Reginald Thomas Pollard, a former member of the House of Representatives, and I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate expresses its deep regret at the death on 24 August 1981 of Mr Reginald Thomas Pollard, a former member of the House of Representatives for the divisions of Ballarat (1937-49) and Lalor (1949-66), and former Minister for Commerce and Agriculture (1946-49), and places on record its appreciation of his long and meritorious public service and tenders its profound sympathy to his family in their bereavement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion which has been moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Carrick). Reg Pollard was a member of the Victorian Parliament for eight years and of the Federal Parliament for 29 years. He was a Minister for six years. He had a long life and a very distinguished one. He is probably best known for his period as Minister for Commerce and Agriculture from 1946 to 1949. He was the architect of the wheat stabilisation scheme. He was responsible for getting Australian agriculture back on its feet after the ravages of the war. He remained close to the farming community throughout his parliamentary life and again in his long retirement.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a matter for some regret, perhaps shame, that Reg Pollard died without any honours or awards being bestowed on him. Whilst all sorts of other people have been handed out the Order of Australia and things of that kind, he received no such award. I guess he was the sort of person who would not have particularly wanted one, but it is a shame that no such honour was extended to him.

He epitomised the Australian parliamentarian in a period when pressures enabled members to be robust and unremitting in debate, yet generous, even gracious, to each other away from the heat of the chamber. He had a distinguished war record. He was wounded in France. He spent three years in the trenches and was commissioned at the front in France. It is ironic that, with that war record, he was defeated in 1966 when the Australian Labor Party suffered severe reverses electorally because of its opposition to the war in Vietnam.

On a personal note, may I say that I grew up in Ballarat, and for part of that period of my childhood Reg Pollard was the member for Ballarat and a Minister in the Chifley Government. I think it is fair to say that he was very highly regarded by the people of Ballarat. I often observe that after his election defeat in Ballarat in 1955 some 25 years passed before the Australian Labor Party regained the seat of Ballarat, which it did at the last election. That gave me great personal satisfaction, as one who remembered the last Labor member, Reg Pollard.

In more recent years Reg Pollard retired and became a farmer at Woodend, a small town in central Victoria. I used to see him there from time to time. He maintained a very keen interest in politics and always gave very sound and frank advice. For example, he never hesitated to say if he thought one had made a mistake, and occasionally he was even given to some form of praise. I have very happy memories of him as a very sensible and lovable man. I have pleasure in seconding the motion moved by Senator Carrick.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join the Australian Democrats in this tribute to the memory of Reg Pollard. When I became a member of parliament he was a serving member. In those 21 years times have changed a little in this place. In my early days the more elderly of the politicians used to cast a benevolent protection over the younger ones who were new to the Parliament. Reg Pollard was one of those people who did that, irrespective of the party to which the younger members belonged. As a member of the Liberal Party at that time I can say that he was a person who was not only respected by the Liberal Party but also feared for the penetration of his contributions to debates. I never heard any member of the Liberal Party or the National Country Party say one ill word about his character or his integrity. In fact, as Senator Button said, he was a man universally respected, indeed loved, in this Parliament. I pay that tribute to him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to be associated with the condolence motion moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Carrick) and supported by the Leader of the Australian Labor Party (Senator Button), firstly, because of Reg Pollard's long service to the Parliament, but more particularly because of his long service to the Australian Labor Party. His whole career was characterised by service to his fellow man. His characteristics endeared him to everybody who knew him, met with him or worked with him. We recognise that as a member of parliament he earned the respect, love and admiration of all sections of the Parliament, a feat which is not achieved by very many. When he joined in debate in the House of Representatives people went into the chamber to listen to his contributions.

SPEECH.PARA: I suppose it would be true to say that if Reg Pollard were to be recalled for one thing it would be for his understanding about the plight of agriculture. He lived through the dark days of the 1930s and the difficult days of the 1940s. He was able to grasp an understanding of the problems in our rural community which perhaps was not matched by many who followed him in the Commerce and Agriculture portfolio. He played a significant part in the post-war rehabilitation of our rural sector. In retrospect, perhaps it is a matter of great regret that the party to which he belonged, and which he loved so much, did not give him a little extra support in the late 1950s, when, had he become leader of the Australian Labor Party, he might well have changed the political history of this country. On that occasion he failed very narrowly in a leadership ballot in the party room, being defeated by Arthur Calwell. He had, perhaps, that little extra public support, understanding and compassion which may well have enabled him to be elected Prime Minister as a result of becoming leader of the Labor Party in that period.

The most important thing that can be said about Reg Pollard is that he had confidence in the future and in humanity itself. He never lost his belief that mankind was capable of better things. He drew inspiration for that belief from his socialist conviction, in which he never wavered despite the many ups and downs of that philosophy over many years. He was able to express that belief in a way that gave confidence to his colleagues and to the younger members of our party. I am sure that those who knew him would agree with me that the Parliament has lost a strong defender of parliamentary democracy, the Labor Party has lost a stalwart and the Australian people have lost a person who made a great contribution to the development of our country in the very difficult times of the 1940s, the 1950s and the 1960s. It is a matter of great regret that in 1966 the Australian people did not understand what the war in Vietnam was about. He was one of the casualties of that, even though he served his country well in World War I. I offer my condolences to his family and place on record my appreciation of his contribution to our party and to the nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McClelland Sen The Hon D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had the honour of serving in the Federal Parliamentary Labor Party with the Honourable Reg Pollard from 1962 to 1966. Not only was he one of the finest parliamentarians I ever knew but also he was one of the greatest Australians I ever knew. He was tough, he was fearless, he was frank, he was open, he was sincere and he was dedicated. When Parliament lost him in 1966 it was one of the great losses suffered by the Federal Parliamentary Labor Party and by the Parliament itself. I well recall his handling of a case on behalf of a constituent who was having difficulty obtaining finance from the War Service Homes Division because the Division claimed that the foundations of the house the constituent was building were sinking. In the adjournment debate in the House of Representatives one night Reg Pollard carried a concrete block on to the floor of the House and placed it next to the Dispatch Box to show that he could carry it and that it would not sink into the ground to the extent claimed. Reg Pollard was a very great Australian. Australians are thankful for what he did for Australia and I certainly mourn his passing.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate: Has the Government indicated in the Budget that it will not allocate any funds for the Burdekin Dam in north Queensland this financial year? Is the Minister aware of the view that construction of the dam must begin within the next 12 months at the latest if the water supply of Townsville is to be assured? Is he aware that the present source of supply, the Ross River Dam, has serious structural defects? Will he give an assurance that the pledge by this Government prior to the last election to build the Burdekin Dam will be honoured?

—The arrangement with the Queensland Government regarding the building of the Burdekin Dam is that all the preparatory stages prior to the building will be done by the Queensland Government. That is why there is no money in this year's Budget for the project; it is because in this year the Queensland Government will be doing the preparatory work. The Commonwealth Government has given a clear undertaking that it will provide the money for the capital works for the actual building of the dam. The Queensland Government will undertake the work on other infrastructure. I am aware of the necessity for the dam. The Commonwealth Government intends to honour its undertaking.

—I preface my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport with the comment that many people in the Pilbara have expressed a desire to have access to regular flights between the Pilbara and an international airport, such as Jakarta or Denpasar, to avoid the extra $340 involved in flying through Perth. All necessary facilities exist at Port Hedland and charter flights are now conducted to and from those airports by Garuda Indonesian Airways and Airlines of Western Australia. As a result of recent amendments to airlines legislation, is Government approval now necessary before regular flights such as those I have mentioned can be initiated?

—Senator Thomas asked whether Government approval was necessary, and I understand that, generally speaking, that would be the situation. However, discussions have taken place between the Western Australian Government and the Minister for Transport on the Western Australian Government's wish to see the early establishment of the service to which Senator Thomas referred. This is certainly being arranged for prompt examination by the Department of Transport. To that end, the Government has established a small group, led by Sir David Hay, to consult with the State governments and some other interested people and advise on the desirable ambit and conduct of that examination. I understand that that group is arranging early discussions with the representatives of the Western Australian Government.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Is the Minister concerned that only some 40,000 people out of an estimated 600,000 or more have applied for disadvantage cards under the new health scheme? Does he consider the advertising campaign conducted to be adequate? Will the Government consider using television and radio, which surely should be used in any modern advertising campaign?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has gone to some trouble to try to ensure that advice about the new health arrangements gets through to those who require it. A substantial number of the people entitled to health cards under the new arrangements-existing pensioner beneficiaries, the unemployed and so on-have to take no action at all because they automatically get the cards. There is a requirement that those people who qualify because of low incomes have to apply if they wish to have the health card. For that reason the Government has been advertising not merely in the print media, as indicated by Senator Grimes, but also on radio. Indeed, the Government has been exploiting various forms of the media to get across the message that people do need to apply, and they have been able to apply during the whole of August for the system which commences on 1 September.

ANSWER.PARA: I have been getting some rather mixed messages from the Opposition. Dr Blewett, the Opposition spokesman on health, has been complaining about the Government's propaganda exercise and about the fact that we are spending money for propaganda purposes. On the other hand, Senator Grimes is concerned that we are not taking enough action through the media to alert people to their entitlements. I have been concerned that an effective message should be getting out to the public. The matter is one I have reviewed, and I will increase the advertising if that seems to be necessary.

As Senator Grimes said, it is true that so far a relatively small proportion of those who are entitled have applied for cards. However, I point out to the Senate that one of the features of this scheme, as against similar schemes in the past, is that it is possible to get entitlement in retrospect. In other words, those people who seek treatment without having previously obtained a card can for 13 weeks after obtaining treatment apply for and obtain a card which will entitle them to reimbursement.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question arising out of the Minister's answer. Would it not be better if some of the money spent on advertising had been spent on radio and particularly on television-I am interested to hear about the radio advertisements; no one else seems to know about them-rather than on putting out the misleading propaganda to which Dr Blewett referred, which omits to mention in any of the pamphlets the 'hospital only' option?

—We have already used a range of media. As I have indicated to the Senate, I am quite happy to examine the matter further because the Government does wish to get this message out effectively. I do not accept that any misleading information has been put out. We have put out a great deal of material to ensure that people's attention is drawn to the features of the new health scheme which will affect them. We will continue to monitor the situation to make sure that those who are supposed to benefit from this scheme do benefit from it.

—Is the Attorney-General aware that the film In the Realm of the Senses by the brilliant Japanese director Oshima was refused showing by the Film Censorship Board unless it was severely cut? Was this film to have been part of a retrospective season of Oshima's work to be shown by the National Film Theatre of Australia to its members? Did the National Film Theatre quite properly refuse to show the film at all as it would have been shown in Oshima's presence and it would have been a great insult to have shown one of his masterpieces in a mutilated form, as re-edited by the Film Censorship Board? Has In the Realm of the Senses been shown uncut at both the Melbourne and Sydney film festivals in the past without noticeable harm to those who saw it? Bearing in mind that the National Film Theatre is a government supported membership organisation of people interested in the art of the film, all aged over 18 years, is not the banning most perverse? Is the explanation to be found in the recent statement by Mrs Strickland, the Chief Censor, that she does not believe that film festivals should be able to show films that other sectors of the adult population cannot see, on the ground that it would be elitist to do so? To avoid a repetition of such a peculiar decision by the Film Censorship Board, will the Attorney-General consider amending the regulations to provide for the special and reasonable requirements of film festivals and the National Film Theatre?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The original version of the film In the Realm of the Senses was shown at the Sydney and Melbourne film festivals in 1977 under an informal agreement whereby films were registered for limited screenings without censorship examination. An important feature of that agreement was that under no circumstances would permission be given for the screening of a film that had previously been refused registration. Later in 1977 this film was imported for commercial exhibition but was refused registration by the Film Censorship Board. An appeal was lodged, but the decision was upheld by the Films Board of Review. A reconstructed version of the film was subsequently lodged in 1977, was registered by the Film Censorship Board and was classified R. An uncut print of the film was submitted for registration by the National Film Theatre in July 1981-its is that decision which Senator Hamer is now complaining about-and was refused registration by the Film Censorship Board on the grounds of indecency and obscenity. The National Film Theatre has appealed against this decision and the appeal has been listed for hearing by the Films Board of Review on 8 September 1981. In light of that appeal I do not propose to make any further comment on the reasons for the Board's refusal or, indeed, to make any comment on the decision.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Hamer raises with me some questions about arrangements regarding film festivals which have been made in the past. I am informed that an informal agreement between the Film Censorship Board, the States and the film festivals in 1975 was entered into whereby practically none of the films screened at festivals are screened by the Film Censorship Board. However, the Chief Censor has always reserved the right to call in a film which might have difficulty in obtaining commercial registration and very occasionally has done so. At the moment I am having discussions with the Chief Censor and officers of my Department responsible for censorship concerning the present regulations under which the Board operates. They also will embrace questions concerning film festivals and the arrangements for them. In conclusion I say that I believe the Film Censorship Board has a very difficult job to do. It has to interpret community standards, which I think is extremely difficult. I do not accept some of the criticisms Senator Hamer seems to have made of it in his question. As to the future of this film, it is in the hands of the Films Board of Review. As to the relationship between the Board and these film festivals or bodies such as the National Film Theatre to which Senator Hamer refers, as I have said, these are matters to which I will be giving further consideration.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. With regard to the Minister's announcement last week that, because of the severe shortage of air traffic controllers, Brisbane Airport would close indefinitely between 9 p.m. and midnight from 10 September and that there would be restrictions on other major airports, some of which service tourist areas, can the Minister advise what positive action he proposes to take to make sure that such drastic measures are not introduced and thereby to ensure that no harm will be done to Queensland's vital tourist industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think this matter was first raised by Senator Martin in the Senate last Wednesday. I was unable to give any particular details as to the situation at Brisbane Airport. However, I pointed out that the Minister and the Department of Transport were extremely concerned about the effect of the shortage of air traffic controllers generally throughout Australia. The Minister has informed me now that a number of options are currently under consideration, one of which is varying rostering principles, shift work and overtime provisions. Discussions are taking place with the Public Service Board regarding concessions for a limited duration in order to ease the immediate problems in Brisbane. Every possible action is being taken to minimise the duration of the limited closure of the airport.

ANSWER.PARA: Although Australia has stepped up its recruitment campaign for air traffic controllers both here and overseas, it will not be possible to overcome the shortfall for some months. TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Social Security seen reports of the views of the Brotherhood of St Laurence that there are over 60,000 unemployed youths in dire poverty? In view of this, why has the Government not indexed the value of the unemployment benefit payable to young unemployed, which is now down to less than $20 per week in 1975 terms, and abolished the Community Youth Support Scheme? Is it the Government's policy to lay the heaviest burden of the recession and its policies on the backs of those who can least bear it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not seen the reports to which the honourable senator refers. Of course, I am aware of the problems of youth unemployment and of the need to take action in that field. Part of the question which the honourable senator asked relates, of course, to matters within the province of the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs. Responding in general terms to the honourable senator's question, I think he would be aware-certainly honourable senators who have been here longer than he has would be aware-that earlier this year the Government undertook a very careful examination of the range of programs which affect 16 and 17-year-olds in the community. Of course, when the Government announced it was going to do that it was fairly typical that there was an immediate campaign-it came mainly from the other side of the chamber-to the effect that we were going to abolish unemployment benefits for 16 and 17-year-olds.

ANSWER.PARA: No doubt the honourable senator will remember that particular controversy. In fact, the Government undertook a very careful review of the range of programs which affect that age group. In addition, of course, it has pursued policies which have seen a very substantial reduction in youth unemployment over the last 12 months. I hope that the honourable senator and all other honourable senators opposite are pleased at the quite substantial reduction of youth unemployment over that 12-month period. The review has resulted in adjustments to a number of programs which affect that age group. Firstly, there have been adjustments to the programs which affect those people who stay at school. There has been an extension of the income test limits which apply to the Secondary Allowances Scheme and to the amounts payable under that scheme. In the area of education there has been an attempt to produce programs which will assist that age group both to stay at school and to benefit from staying at school.

In the field of employment there has been a lot of publicity in the last week about the measures announced in the Budget. The Government has increased by an overall 22 per cent its expenditure in the field of training programs. Whilst attention has tended to be focused on the question of the Community Youth Support Scheme-indeed, there is a matter of public importance for debate today on that subject-less attention has been directed to the fact that in the field of job training and so on there has been a very considerable increase in the amount of funds made available. What the Government has done is to examine the range of programs, whether they are educational or related to job training or to the payment of unemployment benefit. It has tried to produce a balanced range of measures which will meet the needs of people in that age group.

It has not adjusted the unemployment benefit for 16 and 17-year-olds. In part that is because the relationship between the unemployment benefit and the benefits available to those people who remain in education are seen to be out of balance. Hence, we thought it more important to improve the provisions relating to youth remaining at school. But in the totality of provisions for young Australians I think the recent Budget indicates a high level of Government concern and an attempt to arrive at a balance between programs which will be effective in helping that age group.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. Since when has Telecom Australia refused to allow a person to whom a person to person call has been made to advise of his or her availability? This morning I made a person to person call to Hobart and was informed by the Telecom exchange, when the person was not available, that I could not request that that person advise when he or she would be available. Was this done in January in a clandestine manner by Telecom without any notification to members of parliament or the public? In view of the proposed excessive increases in Telecom charges, can the Minister detail by how much Telecom has profited from the dramatic advances in communications technology and why this has not been passed on to Telecom subscribers in the form of cheaper services?

—Senator Harradine asked a question regarding person to person calls. I am advised that a question on this subject has already been answered and is recorded in Hansard of 3 June this year. Telecom Australia has advised that, in the interests of improved efficiency and service to customers, the operating procedures in relation to the particular person service were varied as from February last by introducing a 'try again' service in place of the former 'left word' procedure. The 'left word' procedure relied on the person answering the called number advising the wanted person that the caller wished to make contact. Telecom was not able to ensure that the wanted person received this advice. With the 'try again' procedure Telecom retains responsibility for the connection of particular person unavailable calls. When the wanted person is unavailable the operator will advise the caller, giving all available information. As I understand it, the caller may then inform the operator to keep trying until the wanted person is available. In such a case the operator, if possible, will ascertain when the person will be available, or will attempt to call again in 30 minutes, or will speak to an alternative party at the same number. If it is known that the wanted person can be reached at another number anywhere in Australia the caller may ask the operator to attempt connection to that number, advise the operator to hold the call until he wishes it to be tried again, or cancel the call. The service outlined is available to all telephone customers and does not in any way discriminate against customers who do not have subscriber trunk dialling access.

—Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. My question was as to why Telecom subscribers and members of parliament were not advised about this in January of this year. Moreover, will Telecom reinstate the policy, one which existed for some 40 years, that a person to whom a telephone call is directed may advise when he is available to take the call?

—I am not aware whether subscribers or members of parliament were advised of the change, but I will find out and let the honourable senator know. In the event that they were not, I will ascertain why they were not. I will also direct the attention of the responsible Minister to Senator Harradine's suggestion that the past practice be reinstated.

—Will the Attorney- General inform the Senate what action, if any, will be taken by the Commissioner for Community Relations, the Honourable A. Grassby, in the case of a State Labor member of the New South Wales Parliament, Mr Maurie Keane, deeply offending the Aboriginal and migrant population by his racist statement during a protest meeting in Menai a few days ago?
—I will refer the honourable senator's question to the Commissioner for Community Relations.

—Is the Minister for National Development and Energy aware that on 17 October 1980 representatives of the Stawell, Horsham and Ararat municipalities in Victoria met the Prime Minister and discussed with him the desirability of extending the natural gas pipeline to the Wimmera? What is the Government's attitude to the plight of industrial, commercial and home users of gas in country areas being forced to use reticulated town liquid petroleum gas at exorbitant parity prices? Has the Government received an application from the Victorian Gas and Fuel Corporation for a $21m loan to finance a natural gas pipeline to the Wimmera? If so, when can the community affected expect a reply from the Department of National Development and Energy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was present when the deputation met the Prime Minister. The Government and I, as the responsible Minister, are very keen that States which have access to abundant supplies of natural gas should extend supplies to various areas. Indeed, in New South Wales the Pipeline Authority, under my direction, has just completed a link between Young, Cootamundra and Wagga Wagga and I will be opening that service very soon. Also, as is well known, the natural gas pipeline will soon be extended to Canberra. So it is quite possible for what the honourable senator suggests to be done. That will be done within a tariff that the ordinary consumer will be well able to bear. It is desirable that a number of pipelines be constructed in Victoria, and I imagine that the impetus for that will be given by a recent increase in electricity tariffs. I have no immediate knowledge of a direct approach by the Gas and Fuel Corporation of Victoria for a loan. Indeed, it would not be appropriate for an authority which is part of a government to make such an approach to the Commonwealth.

ANSWER.PARA: There have been discussions between the Commonwealth and Victoria regarding lending. My understanding is that a general extra borrowing process was made available at the last Australian Loan Council meeting. As I understand it, that might well encompass an ability to extend gas pipelines. I say that in the belief that it is now within the competence of the Victorian Government to proceed in that matter. I have no doubt that communications will pass between the Prime Minister and the State regarding the Loan Council deliberations. If, indeed, there were no other source of finance for these pipelines, some three lots of pipelines could be put into position in Victoria, paid for and maintained, with only a very fractional addition to the general tariff for gas in Victoria. The tariff for gas in Victoria is considerably less than in other States, so it is well within the competence of a State such as Victoria to extend its pipelines within its own capacity and within its own finances.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs advise whether the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees has requested Australia to accept Afghan refugees? Considering the plight of refugees in Pakistan and their urgent need for aid, will the Government indicate its attitude towards accepting those refugees? Can the Government indicate also whether it is the belief of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees that Afghan refugees will be returning to their homeland? Could this be one reason why refugees are not being placed in the care of receptive nations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is monitoring events in relation to the movement of roughly 2.2 million Afghan refugees into Pakistan and a reported half million or more into Iran. The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees has not sought to establish a resettlement program for Afghan refugees. To do so might in fact pre-empt diplomatic efforts aimed at achieving a just resolution of the situation in Afghanistan. The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees normally works towards ultimate repatriation of refugees when conditions permit. If the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees were to fail to achieve voluntary repatriation under satisfactory conditions, he would explore next permanent resettlement in the area. Resettlement of refugees in third countries is usually considered only as a last resort.

ANSWER.PARA: Whilst prospects for an early solution of the Afghan situation do not seem encouraging, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees and the Government of Pakistan continue to take the view that ultimately the Afghan refugees will wish to return to their homeland. In the meantime, the refugees should be accorded care and maintenance in the areas where they have sought refuge. The Australian Government's policy is to endorse this approach, and in fact the Government is contributing financially to the work in Pakistan. Whilst there is no resettlement program for refugees from Afghanistan, Afghan refugees with close family or other links with Australia may be considered individually for entry to Australia. Afghans may also apply for entry to Australia under the normal migration program.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Treasurer. With the recent rise in interest rates, many home buyers will be forced to pay over $400 a month in repayments on first and second mortgage loans. Was the rise in interest rates and sales tax a deliberate plan by this Liberal Government to destroy the traditional home life of many Australians, to reduce the population, to foster the divorce rate, to increase the number of homeless children, or to further depress the building industry? If it was not a carefully thought out plan to promote these ills in our society, is it just another example of the Government's bungling with the nation's people and finances?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Budget presented last week certainly was not designed to do any of the things that were suggested in the question asked by Senator Elstob. The Budget was presented as a means of promoting employment opportunities for Australians in the advantages that flow from a Budget that has sound economic management as its base.

ANSWER.PARA: The matter of interest rates for home buyers, which was mentioned by Senator Elstob, is of concern to all those who are aware of the consequences of the raising of interest rates. At the same time, as has been pointed out repeatedly, the availability of home purchase finance depends upon the relativity of interest rates and the other economic factors that need to be taken into account.

As for looking at the Budget in the terms that Senator Elstob mentioned, I would prefer to say that the basis on which the Budget was constructed and the lack of demand that will be made by the Commonwealth Government on the finances of Australia in the forthcoming year will do everything that it is possible for this Government to do to make a contribution to the matters that we think are the positive ones, that is, the security of Australians, the advancement of their opportunities for home ownership and in general their well-being in the economic sense. I would hope Senator Elstob, as he analyses the Budget, will be able to allay his own fears.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: SALES TAX INCREASE: EFFECT ON FOODSTUFFS

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Is the Minister aware of the fact that, for a variety of reasons, it is impossible to purchase any food ultimately in an unwrapped form? Is the Minister therefore aware that, in this Budget, by placing a sales tax on wrapping the Government is effectively increasing the cost of all foodstuffs, whether staple items or luxuries? If the Minister is aware of this effect, will he explain why the Government chose to put this de facto tax on food? If he was not aware of it, will he undertake to discuss with the Treasurer the removal of the forecast sales tax placed on wrapping and hence effectively on foodstuffs?

—It is true that the Government has not placed any sales tax directly on foods; but, as I think Senator Haines has pointed out, matters associated with food may be affected. That is, I think, an inevitability in a sales tax situation; but I will draw the attention of the Treasurer to the question asked by Senator Haines and to her assertion that by increasing the cost of wrapping one is increasing the price of food. I have to say, nevertheless, that the overall effect of the Budget, by the creation of a large domestic surplus, is to depress inflation in Australia and therefore to bear down on costs. In each of the six years that we have presented a Budget the same outcry has occurred. It was the same last year. I remind the Senate that, when the results were shown this year, inflation, as a result of the previous Budget, was down 2 per cent; it was 8.8 per cent. The results were first rate in terms of the performance of other countries. Our economic and monetary policies had worked. They will work again.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. Can the Minister advise the proportion of the 8 per cent air fares increase announced on 11 August that was attributed to the cost of air strikes? Does the Minister believe that underwriting the airlines for loss of revenue in this manner in fact relieves the airlines of the fullest responsibility to have their all too numerous industrial disputes solved as quickly as possible?

—Unfortunately, I do not believe there is any figure or formula by which we can establish the costs in relation to air strikes as directly as Senator Archer would like. Nevertheless, we are able to point out that the average daily revenue of the two major airlines is in the order of $2.5m. Consequently, if the airlines are on strike for any length of time that represents lost revenue of that order that must be recovered in some other way. Obviously the objective of all business undertakings is to make a profit. To achieve that objective they must seek to cover all costs, including losses from industrial action. In this way the airlines are no different from any other business. Permitting the airlines to recover losses from industrial action does not relieve them of the responsibility to resolve industrial disputes as quickly as possible. The fact of the matter is that the airlines have to take into account the costs of a quick settlement, which flow into the cost structure for all time and may be significantly higher in the long run than the cost of resisting unjustified wage demands in the shorter term.

—The Minister representing the Treasurer will be aware that at present people in the Northern Territory have to pay sales tax on the freight component of articles purchased there. Will the Minister indicate whether this iniquitous practice is to continue under the new arrangements and the increased tax?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — As I understand it, there has been no change to sales tax as it applies to freight for those people living in the Northern Territory or indeed any other distant part of Australia. The Bills that are to be introduced, as I understand it, propose no changes in sales tax on freight.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Health aware that at a recent meeting of the Australian Nursing Homes Association a motion urging a State by State basis of representation on the Participating Nursing Homes Advisory Committee was defeated and, as a result, South Australia and Victoria resigned from the ANHA? Does the Minister know that this means that these two States do not have representation on the Participating Committee, which makes decisions affecting nursing homes in those two States? Does the Minister agree that it is to the benefit of both the individual States concerned and the Commonwealth Government to ensure the participation of a delegate from each State in discussions of such importance as the Nursing Homes Participating Scheme? Does the Minister further agree that individual State representation is essential because of the differences between States in laws governing nursing homes? If so, what steps will the Government take to ensure that South Australia and Victoria are represented on this important committee?

—I was not aware of the action taken by those two States at a recent meeting of the Australian Nursing Homes Association. I will convey the substance of Senator Jessop's question to my colleague the Minister for Health. It is obvious that it is desirable that there be an input from all the States in the formulation of such policies. Whether that means that there must be direct representation of the States is not for me to say. I acknowledge Senator Jessop's point that both South Australia and Victoria have information that would be vital in policy formation. I will therefore bring the information to the attention of the Minister concerned.

—Can the Minister for Veterans' Affairs tell me whether he has had any approach from the Western Australian State Minister for Health to relocate the Hollywood Repatriation General Hospital in the A Block of the Sir Charles Gairdner Hospital and to relocate the Sunset Hospital for aged persons from the prime position on the riverfront at Dalkeith to the Hollywood Hospital? Can the Minister say whether this is why the Repatriation Hospital has been allowed to run down in many areas? I instance staffing, the theatre block, the failure to complete air conditioning to three wards and the closure of ward 13.

—I would need to check the details of a number of the matters Senator McIntosh referred to concerning the Hollywood and Sunset hospitals. He asked me whether any approach had been made by the State Minister for Health with regard to the Sir Charles Gairdner Hospital. There has been some brief discussion between him and me on the telephone about the whole area of health policy affecting the Hollywood Hospital, but I have had nothing in detail from him; nor have we discussed any matter in detail at all.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: CODE OF CONDUCT FOR AUSTRALIAN COMPANIES IN SOUTH AFRICA

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Prime Minister to my question without notice of 5 March 1981 relating to the codes of conduct adopted by different countries whose companies have active operations in South Africa. In answering my question, the Minister stated:

QUESTION.PARA: The question of establishing a code of conduct for Australian firms operating in South Africa is being considered further. Officials are currently examining the practice of other countries with more extensive commercial involvement in South Africa.

In view of the concern being expressed by the Australian community, including the Australian Council for Overseas Aid, about our relations with South Africa and the Government's firm and consistently stated opposition to apartheid, I ask the Minister: Firstly, has consideration now been given by the Government to the various anti-apartheid and employment codes or practices of other countries with extensive commercial involvement in South Africa? Secondly, when will a similar code of conduct be adopted or developed to ensure that Australian companies with active operations in South Africa do not contribute to the strength of the apartheid policy? Thirdly, what additional action will be taken by the Australian Government to increase its diplomatic and economic pressure on the Government of South Africa to terminate apartheid in all its forms?

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Missen has raised basically three matters. My understanding is that the matter of a code of conduct for Australian firms operating in South Africa remains under serious consideration. This consideration extends to examination of codes of conduct which have been introduced by other countries but which are not mandatory-for example, those of the United States of America, Canada and the European Economic Community. As to the second matter, I regret that I cannot give Senator Missen a timetable for the introduction of an Australian code of conduct. The honourable senator would be aware that the subject is a complex one. As to the third part of his question, there should be no doubt about the Australian Government's strong and unequivocal opposition to apartheid. The Government has shown by its actions-such as the denial of visas to the Springbok rugby team, its adherence to the Gleneagles agreement on sporting contacts, its decision against Qantas Airways Ltd resuming flights to Johannesburg and other matters-that it maintains its position of strong opposition to apartheid. This policy is continually under review by the Government in the light of developments in South Africa. I will bring the question to the attention of the relevant Minister and see whether there is any further information that can be given.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Attorney-General whether earlier this year he wrote to an honourable senator in his own party in relation to copyright provisions saying, amongst other things:

QUESTION.PARA: The Parliamentary Library advised that it was of the view that the provision of copies of material to members when they were away from Parliament House and required it urgently for the performance of their duties could be met administratively. They advised that in such cases the material could be selected and sent on the basis that the member would on receipt fill in and send back the request and declaration by return mail.

Is the Attorney-General aware of a statement by the librarian of a State Parliament that he, the Attorney-General, is reported as condoning breaches of the law proposed by the Australian Parliamentary Library to cushion the impact of the copyright legislation on Commonwealth members? Is the Attorney-General in fact condoning a breach of the law and, if he is not, can he explain how the librarian to whom I referred has erred?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, the application of the new provisions of the Copyright Act in relation to photocopying, particularly in parliamentary libraries but also in libraries that are serving people in remote areas, has given a good deal of concern to a number of people, including, I must admit, the officers of my Department who have been looking at it. When the legislation was before the Parliament the question was raised in the Senate debate, if I remember rightly. The views of the Federal Parliamentary Librarian were ascertained by some senators and were canvassed here. It appeared that there might be an administrative solution to the problem which would facilitate making this material available in the way in which I think Senator Colston has correctly indicated.

ANSWER.PARA: I have been having a look at the problem since then. I am aware that contrary views have been expressed by State librarians. I have had representations from State members. Indeed, it was raised at the recent meeting of the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General. In view of the amount of concern that has been expressed, as I said, I am having the matter looked at again. It may well be that some amendment may be proposed to clarify the position. I do recognise that there is a problem. It certainly has not been decided whether it can be solved administratively. If I have said anything that may have indicated that the view I have expressed is not the correct view of the law, I assure the Senate that it is not due to my condoning it. Perhaps I have stated a mistaken view of the provisions, although I do not believe that it is necessarily mistaken. As I said, it is one of these areas where there are doubts, and I am hoping to have them clarified.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. In the light of the discussion on the entry of foreign banks into Australia, is the Treasurer aware that there are now 25 merchant banks operating in Australia, that 64 per cent of these are foreign-owned or majority controlled and that a further 32 per cent have a significant foreign element in their shareholding? How has this happened when the Foreign Investment Review Board guidelines state that there must be at least 50 per cent Australian equity in such undertakings? What does the Treasurer plan to do to ensure that equity is taken up by Australians in this area?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — When looking at foreign banks, we need to understand that until 1973 the Australian Government did not impose any restrictions at all, on foreign policy grounds, on the entry of foreign interests into the merchant banking industry. Up until that time a number of foreign interests took up the majority, or in some cases 100 per cent, ownership of new or existing Australian merchant banks. The guidelines of the Government's policy on foreign investment in the non-banking financial sector require that proposals for the establishment of a new merchant bank must show substantial net economic benefits to Australia to obtain approval. Where the net economic benefits are small, it must involve an effective partnership between Australian interests and the various investors in the ownership and control of the company concerned. In some cases approval may be more readily granted where a financial intermediary's operations are strictly ancillary to other business operations, for example, an in-house financier, and do not have significant implications for the financial sector.

ANSWER.PARA: I am advised that all proposals to acquire or increase substantially interests in an existing merchant bank are closely examined regardless of the size of the company concerned. Again, substantial benefits must be demonstrated, taking account of the implications of the proposal for the financial sector and for the level of Australian ownership. In such cases the parties would have been required to demonstrate that Australian investors had been given prior opportunity to acquire the interest on reasonable terms. Under these guidelines, foreign investment has been restricted accordingly. It has not been the Government's policy to require foreign interests to advise of their shareholdings so that Australian ownership in all merchant banks is 50 per cent. I think Senator Watson also asked me whether the Treasurer would take any action with regard to this. I will refer the matter to the Treasurer to seek further advice on that point.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Has she seen an article by Douglas Wilkie in today's issue of the Melbourne Sun? The article suggests that the recent downing of two Libyan aircraft over the Mediterranean was part of the scene 'for a Western strategic counter-thrust in North Africa to redress setbacks in Iran and Afghanistan'. Did United States military leaders urge President Carter to grant Egypt the go-ahead to invade Libya, as this article suggests? Will the Australian Government take any such scenario into account before Australian troops are posted to the Sinai as part of a peacekeeping force?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I do not know that I am able to deal precisely with the questions raised by Senator Primmer. The information I have from the Minister for Foreign Affairs with regard to Libya and the aircraft is that he is aware of reports that Colonel Gaddafi has said that the two Libyan fighters shot down by the United States Navy fighters on 19 August fired first. He is reported to have said that the Libyan aircraft were under orders to protect Libyan air space from intruders and had therefore attacked after their warning to the United States aircraft to depart had been ignored.

ANSWER.PARA: It has now been confirmed that the incident occurred in the geographical area of the Gulf of Sidra, further out than the 12-mile limit which we understand is claimed by Libya as territorial sea along the rest of its coast. Libya has claimed the Gulf as an historic bay since October 1973. That claim has not been generally recognised by the international community, including Australia, and a number of countries, including the United States, have specifically rejected it. It is therefore apparent that the incident occurred over international waters, where international law recognises the right of military and commercial overflight.

The Government rejects the characterisation of the United States exercise in the Gulf of Sidra as a form of provocation. United States forces have carried out such exercises a number of times in the past and in all cases have given proper and timely notice of them. Any nation has the right to conduct properly military exercises in international waters, and in no circumstances can the exercise of that right give legal justification for an armed attack. The Government is pleased that the incident has been an isolated one and that both parties have taken action under the United Nations Charter to report the matter to the Security Council. I will refer the other part of Senator Primmer's question to the Minister and seek information for him.

TALK.START.PARA: —I preface my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport by saying that the Minister is no doubt aware of Press reports that Qantas Airways Ltd is examining the purchase of twin-engine aircraft, such as the Boeing 767 or the Airbus A310, to supplement its existing all-747 fleet. Can the Minister advise what stage Qantas has reached in those evaluations? Can the Minister also comment on the fact that Qantas moved from smaller capacity aircraft to the Boeing 747? What management reasoning has occurred to justify the airline's re-thinking on the capacity? Finally, is the Qantas move designed to pre-empt any chance of the domestic airlines operating on regional routes, such as those from Port Hedland, perhaps Darwin, Townsville and Hobart, with aircraft of a more suitable size?

—Senator Townley is probably correct in assuming that the Minister knows something about the matters to which he has referred, but I am afraid I have no particular information with which I can help him. I will need to refer to the Minister all the points that the honourable senator raised in his question and obtain an early reply.

—I address my question to the Minister for Finance. As a member of the ministerial committee reviewing Government functions, the Minister will be aware that the Australian Wool Corporation has been instructed to sell the 12 stores it controls in Palmyra, Western Australia. Have prospective buyers been told that the Corporation does not own the stores it has been instructed to sell? If they have been told, what arrangements, if any, have been made to legally transfer these properties, which are now owned by the Western Australian Cemeteries Trust, to private enterprise?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I am well aware of the decision that was taken by the committee which reviewed Commonwealth functions but I am not aware of the details with regard to information given to prospective buyers or arrangements made for transfer of the stores. I will need to have that matter referred to the Minister concerned. I will see that Senator McLaren is given advice as soon as possible.

—Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. I now ask the Minister: When the decision was taken to sell properties such as this was not information before the razor gang as to who owned the properties which the Government is trying to sell to raise money to bolster its finances?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — A number of decisions were taken by the committee which reviewed Commonwealth functions and they were taken for a diversity of reasons. In many cases the decisions were taken to streamline the responsibilities of government and to ensure that, where matters could be properly undertaken outside of government, this would occur. With regard to the stores concerned, it was considered that certain action should be taken and, as I have said, I will seek what information has been given to prospective buyers with regard to them.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Health aware of statements made by the Australian Labor Party spokesman on health that the new rates set by health insurance funds are unrealistically low? How does this statement compare with earlier predictions by the Labor Party about certain high costs of health insurance for families after 1 September?

—When the new health measures were announced a lot of scaremongering went on and this is just another example. The fact is that the health funds do not set their own contribution rates. They submit proposals for new rates to the Department of Health and to a registration committee. The Australian Government Actuary is a member of the committee. The proposed rates are not approved if, in the expert opinion of the committee, they would endanger the viability of a fund. It is simplistic to consider the financial health of an insurance fund in terms only of its contribution rates. The financial positions of the funds vary according to past operations, the structure of their membership and so on. Many funds have financial reserves well in excess of the guidelines used by the registration committee. They can and do use these free reserves to cushion the impact of health cost increases on contribution rates. This is surely good business practice. The Department of Health regulates the operations of the health funds and closely monitors their viability. The Press reports claiming that the new contribution rates are dangerously low really reflect the sour grapes attitude of people opposite whose predictions about massive increases simply did not eventuate.

—My question is directed to the Minister for National Development and Energy. By way of preface I remind the Minister of the previous questions I have asked in relation to the 100 drums of waste material which are currently in Singapore awaiting return to Australia. Is the Minister aware that the 100 drums of waste recently had to be repacked because of corroding of the original packaging? Is he aware of claims by the Singapore Government that shipping companies are not keen on accepting those drums as cargo back to Western Australia? Is the Minister also aware of an article appearing in the West Australian of 17 July which quotes an Australian High Commission spokesman as saying that 'the Australian Government has set aside a disposal site in Western Australia', whilst a spokesman for the Western Mining Corporation claims that the waste will be stored at Kambalda when it is returned? Will the Minister advise whether the Australian Government has surveyed or selected a site or whether this has been left to the company concerned, and what control the Government will exercise over the safe containment of the drums prior to and during transportation, on arrival and in the continuing oversighting of the safety of the site and the containers in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Coleman will be aware, of course, that this mishap happened when a measuring instrument which contained some caesium radioactive materials was inadvertently sent to Singapore with some scrap metal and went into a furnace. There are many of these measuring instruments around. Indeed, discussions are taking place between the Commonwealth and the States at this moment to see how we can get an orderly, relatively uniform and highly efficient method of ensuring continuing auditing of them.

ANSWER.PARA: I have been asked for a great deal of information on this matter. I am asked by Senator Coleman whether the material had to be repacked. My understanding is that some of the drums were not considered to be thoroughly efficient and so in fact they were crumpled up and put into new drums. Expert scientists gave the advice that the packing would be perfectly safe, that the methods to be used would be safe and that there would be no damage to the health of anybody in the trans-shipment of the material. We are not relying on any political judgment in this matter. We are relying on the advice of the experts. If Senator Coleman would like more specific advice I would be happy to give it.

The Western Australian Government has the responsibility for the final disposal of the material. The material itself, as I am technically advised, is quite capable of reasonable and safe disposal and it is not anticipated that there will be any trouble in that regard. I am not aware of difficulties with the shipping companies. As a regular practice, radioactive material, including measuring instruments, is transferred around the world. The honourable senator must realise that in the ordinary daily life of the community a very considerable amount of industrial and medical radionuclides are moved around. Whilst every precaution is taken, from time to time there is some incident. We are taking all the precautions that the scientific advisers tell us are necessary to ensure the safe movement.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. In my question I asked what responsibility the Government would accept not only for the safe containment of the drums prior to and during transportation but also for the continuing oversighting of the site and the containers on arrival in Australia.

—Upon arrival in Australia the matter of handling is one for the Western Australian Government. The Western Australian Government and other State Governments are consistently responsible for the handling of radioactive materials of law radiation. The Western Australian Government will be responsible for the disposal. As to the nature of the packing, the Commonwealth has sought the advice of experts, and those experts have said that the procedures that are being undertaken are fully safe. That is how it will be proceeded with. I stress that every day there is movement around Australia of radioactive material.
—Very careless movement, I must stress, on many occasions.

—I have to say to Senator Coleman that discussions are now under way between the Commonwealth and the States to see whether we can tighten up so that we get not only a code for the handling of what in this case is relatively low radioactivity but also radioactivity. We are discussing a uniform code for all radioactivity just as we have a uniform mining code. I ask that further questions be placed on notice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I rise more in sorrow than in anger to question the decision that the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Carrick) has made in asking that further questions be placed on notice. Honourable senators will be aware of the song Never on Sunday. The difference in this instance is that some honourable senators do not get the opportunity to ask a question on two consecutive sitting days. I deliberately watched Question Time today and last Thursday. Senator Carrick's defence has always been that supplementary questions erode the time available for questions. That is true. However, a minimum number of supplementary questions was asked today. There is something wrong with parliamentary democracy if senators, in a House of 64, cannot ask questions more frequently than members of another place, which has double the membership of the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: The matter goes a little further. I commend to Senator Carrick the words of Zapata, the Mexican revolutionary hero, who said: 'It is better to die on your feet than to live on your knees'. I make that point because it is all very well for Senator Carrick to say that honourable senators will be able to ask a question on the third sitting day but by that time history has already passed by some of the matters honourable senators want to ventilate. I have a final warning on this matter: We have a very evenly balanced Senate. If the Government wants to keep the rank and file quiet and contented the Leader of the Government in the Senate and Mr President will have to devise a much more effective formula because it is utter rubbish for them to blame supplementary questions. Senator Carrick can do better and he knows it. His Government strategy will have to take second place to the wishes of other honourable senators from now on.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-A couple of times during Question Time I was about to rise on a point of order but did not do so because I did not want to take up time. Government senators in particular have a practice of giving notice to Government Ministers of the questions they wish to ask.
—Dorothy Dixers.

—I do not object to that one bit, if the responsible Minister is not a member of the Senate. I would much rather that that were done. If an honourable senator asks a question of a Minister representing a Minister in the House but does not give the Minister some notice, all the honourable senator will get is: 'I will refer it to the responsible Minister'. It is much better to have some proper reply.

SPEECH.PARA: Last week and today I noticed that replies being provided by Ministers in those circumstances have been a little overenthusiastic in their length. Probably Ministers do not realise this but today a great amount of time was taken up with such replies. The time that Ministers took to answer questions asked by Government senators was, on the average, about double the time it took to answer questions from honourable senators on this side of the House. That was through nobody's fault. I am asking that when Ministers read prepared answers they precis them and cut them down to size so that we can get more questions in.
