DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Grimes proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The abolition of the Community Youth Support Scheme and the need for a community based training and employment program.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussions to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by sessional order having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, may I be the first to congratulate you on your election to your new office. I am pleased to be the first to speak in the Senate following your taking the chair in that position. I hope that in the years ahead you will have no difficulty in this place. I am sure that we will have fair treatment from you, as we have had in the past. As one of the more placid members of the Senate, I can say that you will have no difficulty with me. I will endeavour to make sure that my colleagues, some of whom are a little more lively, will not cause any trouble.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition needs no justification for bringing up the abolition of the Community Youth Support Scheme this week as a matter of public importance. The Press, indeed the media in general, have commented on this move in the Budget for a week now, but it is impossible to find any commentator, any expert in the area, or anyone who is active in regard to youth unemployment, who supports the Government's decision. It was sprung on us in the Budget. The scheme has been abolished without replacement by a substitute community scheme and, for that reason, the Budget proposal has been much criticised.

Not only has the abolition of the scheme caused concern, but also the manner in which the Government and the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr N. A. Brown) have deceived the community and those involved in the scheme concerning what was going on has been reprehensible and such as should be avoided at all costs when human lives and jobs are concerned. The deception is reminiscent of the abolition of the Australian Assistance Plan by this Government in its early days in office. That was done without notice by a curt announcement at a meeting of State Ministers and with neither satisfactory public explanation nor parliamentary debate.

I repeat that the Minister and the Government have behaved in a reprehensible and deceptive manner, one which is typical of the standards which they have displayed generally. Even more, they have shown a complete lack of concern for the people who have used CYSS-the project officers and tutors who have been employed by the scheme and those altruistic members of the community who have supported it and worked very hard on its committees.

On August 20, two days after the presentation of the Budget, the Minister wrote to every honourable member and senator in this place announcing the release of a colourful chart which described the employment, training and youth programs that were available from the Government, and his Department in particular. Prominent on that expensively prepared chart is a reference to the Community Youth Support Scheme. Thus, in a letter dated two days after the Budget was brought down, the Minister produced, I imagine for honourable senators to put up in their offices, a deceptive chart, one which was out of date when it was produced. The Minister and his Department must have had knowledge of the demise of the scheme when the chart was produced, yet proceeded with its production. That was the final act in a series of events which led up to this budgetary decision, a decision which has disturbed and disappointed so many people of good will in the community. Some project officers under the scheme were employed only a couple of weeks before the Budget announcement came that as from 1 October they would lose their jobs. At least one individual-I understand there were more-had left other employment to take up work with the Community Youth Support Scheme. Why should someone not have taken up such a job with confidence?

The Minister concerned, the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs, allegedly an honourable man, had never given any suggestion to the CYSS groups or to the community that the scheme would not continue. In fact he had assured the community and members of the Community Youth Support Scheme that the scheme would continue in the future. There was no suggestion in the report of the razor gang-the report put down by Sir Phillip Lynch and his colleagues-that there would be complete abolition of the scheme. The Minister, Mr Brown, in his statements was quite supportive of the program. Referring to the Minister, the Adelaide Advertiser of 2 June 1981 reported:

Commonwealth funded youth support schemes need not fear coming changes to funding and operations . . . He said the changes would be aimed at making the service 'run smoothly and consistently'. Changes would include paying CYSS grants in lump sum in advance rather than reimbursing projects at a later date. He said this means grants could be given to a project in advance, according to an estimate on the project, and that money could be given to a project in advance, according to an estimate on the project, and that money could be used by project administrators in any way . . . Mr Brown also said he would like to see more work-oriented schemes under CYSS.

Who would not? The Launceston Examiner of 22 August 1981 quoted a letter written by Mr David Thompson, the State Executive Officer of the CYSS projects in Tasmania. The letter was dated 14 July and was sent to all CYSS projects in Tasmania. It stated:
Mr Brown-
That is, the Minister--
has decided that any changes to the CYSS guidelines and grant payments procedures will not be implemented until May, 1982.
From now until the beginning of May, you-
That is, the project officers--
should continue to operate according to the current CYSS guidelines and administrative arrangements.

There was no suggestion in that letter or in the report in the Adelaide Advertiser that CYSS was to be abolished. There was no suggestion that employment within the Scheme was not secure or that anything was to change. In fact, the letter and the Minister's statement were quite supportive of the Scheme. Only two weeks before the Budget announcement Mr Brown spoke to Mr Braid, M.L.C., a member of the Upper House in Tasmania, certainly not a supporter of the Australian Labor Party but a supporter of CYSS and a man who worked on CYSS projects. He reassured Mr Braid that CYSS projects would continue, that the guidelines would be reviewed, and that the functions of all the projects would continue to receive Government support. That was two weeks before the Budget announcement. However, Mr Brown said in his Budget statement:
While CYSS has been a valuable program, circumstances have changed since CYSS was first introduced in 1976.

That apparently justifies the demise of CYSS. But what has changed? Have we no longer any unemployed youth? In fact there are greater numbers of unemployed youth now than there were in 1976, when the project was introduced. Are many of them still not in need of the sort of support they are getting from the CYSS project? Has the problem of homeless youth diminished? Certainly those of us on the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare investigating this problem do not believe that it has diminished; all the evidence is that it has increased. Those people still need support. The only thing that has changed in the two months since Mr Brown uttered his supportive words in Adelaide, and in the few weeks since he uttered his supportive words in Tasmania, is that the conservative elements in Cabinet, the Government and the Treasury who are so suspicious of community programs, have got the upper hand and destroyed this project.
Mr Brown went on to say in his statement attached to the Budget:

The Government considers the most practical way it can help the young reap the benefits of a growing economy is to provide increased education, training and work experience opportunities, so that they improve their skills and better compete in the growing labour market. No young person, in need, will be denied assistance to make a successful transition to the world of work.

Of course, the jobs are not there; the young people will simply be denied work. I ask the Senate: Is the Minister suggesting that, by the time CYSS is killed in October this year, the Government will have the employment, training and transitional education programs to cope with the 54,000-odd young people who use CYSS facilities or the tens of thousands more young people who would have used those facilities if the guidelines for the scheme had been broadened to include activities involved in job placement, special counselling, and programs to do with productive activity? We are told, correctly, that the Government is to increase funding for the Special Youth Employment Training Program, but the Government's own figures demonstrate that there can be only 8,000 to 10,000 more positions under that program. The Government at various times has praised the voluntary youth program. We know from what Mr Viner has said in recent times that only 300 people have taken advantage of that. The Government cannot be serious in saying that the work done by CYSS, and the youth looked after by CYSS, will be looked after by those other programs by October this year.

Many evaluations of the Community Youth Support Scheme have been undertaken by the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs, by the Government, and by independent authorities. None of the results of those Government evaluations has been publicly released. This Parliament has not had the opportunity to debate such reports or to consider what sort of advice the Government has been getting. In April 1980 Mr Viner announced a national review to investigate the Community Youth Support Scheme, to provide for means whereby the Scheme could be consolidated and rationalised. Where is that report? Why cannot this Parliament judge the efforts of the committee that made that investigation? Why cannot we make a judgment on the Government's decision? We do not know what reports to the Government have recommended but we believe with confidence that they certainly did not recommend the sorts of changes this Government has initiated in the Budget. We believe those reports recommended the sorts of changes that the project officers and others have long advocated for CYSS-changes to the guidelines to make the scheme more effective.

Reports from independent groups from Melbourne University and the Swinburne College of Technology in Melbourne both commented on the lower incidence of crime, drug-taking and other anti-social activities among those attending the various CYSS projects in Melbourne. Some 52,000 people are attending 270 CYSS groups in this country. There are 850 CYSS officers, including those who participate in job sharing and who work part-time. Over 1,000 part-time tutors and assistants and many more people have given valuable voluntary time to CYSS. There are other spin-offs. People associated with CYSS, both voluntary helpers and paid project officers, are often associated with other projects to assist unemployed youth. They have worked in establishing work co-operatives. In particular, they have established and worked in the youth refuges, the hostels and the crisis centres which have been needed to cope with the unemployed homeless youth in our community. They became aware, by their association with CYSS and with the unemployed youth who attended CYSS groups, of the other needs of those young people, of the desperate shortcomings in the lives of the young people. What is to happen to those people, many of whom have given up other jobs and careers to work in the CYSS project?

The Government indirectly recognised the need for and the value of the Community Youth Support Scheme by increasing the funding for it each year even though that funding, we believe, has been inadequate. In 1979 Mr Viner, recognising the situation, wrote to the then Minister for Finance asking for extra funds-another $3m in fact-for the Community Youth Support Scheme. He said in that letter:

As you are aware there is strong local support for CYSS projects in many areas and it is considered that large-scale reductions in number of projects or level of funding for particular projects would inevitably lead to adverse criticism from local communities as well as from Members, Senators and other sources.
Of course Mr Viner was right. The support was well justified.

The labour force figures released by the Australian Bureau of Statistics revealed that, in May 1981, 116,000 people aged from 15 to 19 were unemployed and 78,700 people aged from 20 to 24 were seeking work in the community. The average duration of unemployment for the 15-year-olds to 19-year-olds was 23 weeks and for the 20-year-olds to 24-year-olds it was 35.2 weeks. In my own town in the last few weeks over 500 young people have applied for 40 jobs in a newly established business there. The situation is a tragedy. Not only can we not provide jobs for our young but also we are about to pull from under them one of the few supporting programs that we have had and the only community based program that was successful. No one, certainly not myself and certainly not the project officers, believed that the CYSS was perfect. No one disagrees with the suggestion that the guidelines were inadequate and unnecessarily restrictive and that a greater degree of emphasis could have been placed on counselling and training. Some projects, we know, were better than others. But none of these things is a reason to abolish the Scheme completely, essentially without notice, and leave a vacuum.

Those who worked in and with the CYSS, as with the Australian Assistance Plan, have demonstrated that there was the desire, the ability and the good will in the community to support and help our unemployed youth face a difficult future. As much as anything else, the sudden deceitful abolition of the CYSS, together with the failure to increase the unemployment benefit for those under the age of 18 and the failure to index the unemployment benefit for those over 18 years of age, the harsh restrictions on the work test, the constant denigration of the young unemployed as dole bludgers et cetera and the criticism of their attitude, demonstrates, and can only demonstrate, to the youth of this country that their elected government puts them at the bottom of the list in its priorities. We as a society, I believe, will reap the bitter rewards of this policy. I am afraid that the demonstration which took place at the Liberal Party headquarters last week will not be the last.

The community and individuals in our community are willing to help but they need assistance. The employment of project officers, the provision of the meagre facilities and what, in budgetary terms, is a very small amount of money should have been improved upon and should have been developed, not abolished. We have again missed an opportunity to do something to assist our youth to have greater self-esteem, greater confidence and a feeling that society is concerned for them. We can no longer tell our children that the rewards of work and study at school is a job and a place in society. We do not provide the jobs. We provide completely inadequate support. We now deny the community itself the opportunity to assist. The resulting frustration, anger and distress will be manifest, I believe, only too visibly in the future and all the wringing of hands by those who are responsible for this policy will be to no avail.

We in the Opposition therefore urge the Government to reconsider its decision. We are not uncritical supporters of the CYSS. We believe it could have been improved. We believe these people could have been assisted in many ways so as to achieve a more meaningful program, such as getting greater numbers of unemployed involved, but nothing that the Government has suggested will take the place of the CYSS as it exists in so many places in this community. Nothing the Government has on offer will help the community assist its own young people or help the community to set the priorities in dealing with the very real problem of unemployed youth. It is for this reason that we believe this Parliament, not only members in this House but also in the other place, should on this day discuss this matter and urge the Government to reconsider the decision that it has taken.

The second change to which I refer is the development of new programs. In 1981-82 the Government's emphasis on assistance to the young unemployed will continue, in particular through the Special Youth Employment Training Program, under which it is expected that there will be nearly 90,000 placements of young people in 1981-82. There will be increased subsidies under the Program to assist those young people who have been unemployed for eight months or more in the last 12 months. There will be an increase in the range of educational opportunities for young people experiencing difficulty in the transition from school to work under the Commonwealth School to Work Transition Program. There is available also a transition allowance. This allowance is $42 a week for under-18-year-olds and $64.10 a week for over-18-year-olds. The availability of the transition allowance is being extended this year to ensure that young unemployed people do not lack an incentive to undertake technical and further education courses. This year there is to be a strengthening of the counselling services which are available through the Commonwealth Employment Service to young unemployed people. I have already mentioned the CRAFT program-that is, the Commonwealth Rebate for Apprentice Full-time Training program-which this year will receive $72m for the training of about 95,000 apprentices.

To summarise these points, I should note that the expenditure on all employment and youth affairs programs has increased by 23 per cent in this Budget to $203m. Of that, $156m-that is, 77 per cent of all those programs-is directed at young people. The two programs that most relate to the Community Youth Support Scheme-that is, the School to Work Transition Program and SYETP-will this year receive $79.4m, which is a 67 per cent increase in funding. When the economy is growing and when greatly increased job opportunities are becoming available to young people as much as they are to the community at large, it is the Government's view that employment opportunities for the young will best be encouraged by the most practical schemes of giving increased education, training and work experience opportunities.

Whilst a number of CYSS programs did assist in this way, in general it is true that the Community Youth Support Scheme provided a group which could draw unemployed young people away from loneliness and from a complete shattering of their self-confidence. These people were able to reach out to a wider group, to meet with representatives of the local community and to be encouraged to think about the kinds of skills required before actually gaining a job.

These activities are still important. Under CYSS they were only the tip of the iceberg of community support. That iceberg and the community are still there. Youth and church groups, local and State government initiatives and various programs of neighbourly advice for young people will still be available not only in the city but also in the country areas and in local communities. There will not be that institutionalised tip of the iceberg which has been evident for five years during the operation of CYSS. In placing a consolidated priority upon those practical schemes that give direct educational, work experience or training opportunities to young people, the Government is not denying that great mass of the iceberg of community support which has always been in place for young people and which continues even now.

It has been asked whether the Government would consider alternative sources of funding for individual CYSS projects that have been seen to be worth while. It has been suggested that if, say, one-third of the CYSS projects had been seen to be especially productive they should gain some further Commonwealth assistance. The Government's answer to this suggestion is no. The Government believes that the CYSS program has fulfilled its purpose in the five years of its existence and that the most practical way now of ensuring that young people are in a position to take advantage of the growing labour market is to provide increased financial assistance to those programs that give directly education, training and work experience opportunities. In summary, the people of Australia expect any government to assess and evaluate programs from time to time and to see whether the circumstances in which a program was born, and in which it needs to carry on, continue to exist. The Fraser Government is not a government that will be ruled by Topsy, that will allow programs to grow and never be cut off, and that will never prune the grapevine. The Government had the razor gang Committee of Review of Commonwealth Functions prune away about 1.5 per cent of current Government expenditure.

In the area of youth unemployment programs, whilst there has been a massive increase in funding in this Budget, there has also been this degree of pruning. The circumstances now are not the same as those of five years ago. There have been improvements in youth employment and a range of other successful programs which generate youth employment have been consolidated. The priority now is to consolidate our efforts into the areas which are proven to be the most successful. It is not a decision which has been made because there has been a careful six-month analysis of the Scheme and it has not been made because the Community Youth Support Scheme has not generated a large number of successful graduates, as it were, who go on to employment. It is understood that the scheme is more preliminary than that. Along with all the other informal community support programs in the country, it is the first step towards the school-to-work transition programs which show much greater success scores in terms of the graduates at the end of the courses who go on to employment. The decision has not been made for these reasons; CYSS has been discontinued because it was a five year exercise which has proved its worth, and times now are different. The time has come to give priority to the practical schemes that provide increased education, training and work experience opportunities to young people so that they improve their skills and better compete in the growing labour market.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Along with the hike in indirect taxation, the abolition of the Community Youth Support Scheme is perhaps the most glaring example in this year's Budget of the callous disregard this Government has for the people of Australia. In this case, the move to get rid of CYSS will leave thousands of unemployed young people without any assistance or support to cope with their plight or to help them to find work. Contrary to what Senator Teague has said, it will also throw out of work about 1,000 youth workers who will have to go on the dole after CYSS funding ends on 1 November. This is the last community-based self-help organisation which this Government has put into the wastepaper basket, having got rid of the Regional Employment Development scheme, the Australian Assistance Plan and the Area Improvement Program.

SPEECH.PARA: The responsibility for the consequences of this move will lie fairly and squarely on the shoulders of the Treasurer (Mr Howard) and the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr N. A. Brown). It is significant that the Government has not seen fit to have a Minister defend the abolition of the Community Youth Support Scheme. Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, who represents the Treasurer and the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs, has not been prepared to get up and defend the indefensible. Mr Howard claimed on Budget night that the abolition of CYSS would 'allow available funds to be concentrated on programs more attuned to labour market conditions'. The most glaring facts about labour market conditions are that 375,000 people are out of work, according to official estimates, and that 14.9 per cent of 15 to 19-year-olds are out of work. If the Treasurer really took notice of these conditions, schemes aimed specifically at helping these young people would be encouraged and not abolished.

Today, outside this Parliament, young CYSS workers and participants have gathered to protest against the abolition of the Scheme, which was one of the few signs that something was being done about their plight. They now feel as though the one small piece of firm ground they had has been taken out from underneath them. Some of those young people have made known their views to members of the Opposition and to the Government. They told me that CYSS provided help for the young people who more often than not never see, let alone take part in, the Government's much vaunted training schemes. The Scheme reaches the alienated young person who is convinced that no one cares about his or her problem. For example, in my State alone well over 5,000 young people will have received assistance through the Community Youth Support Scheme. This Scheme, more than any other-more than even the Commonwealth Employment Service-helped young people find work. It just shows to what extent Government senators do not know what is going on. They do not even read or understand the Government's own papers because Budget Statement No. 7 forecasts a slowing down in the rate of growth of employment from 2.6 per cent last year to 2 per cent in 1981-82. It is interesting to note that the same document refers to the fact that the employment of juniors grew by 2.9 per cent in the current financial year compared with a growth of 5.6 per cent in the previous year. So much for Senator Teague's defence of the indefensible. The Government admits that only 23,000 people will benefit as a result of its retraining schemes.

TALK.START.PARA: —But there has been a considerable improvement.

—Of course, the Budget makes provision for increases in the number of social security payments to the unemployed. So I say to Senator Teague that the Government acknowledges that there will be a worsening of the position, not an improvement. Of course, the young people themselves have confirmed what the Australian Council of Social Service has said-I quote the Council-that CYSS is a unique program unparallelled in other Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries and one that is recognising that young people experiencing unemployment may need support and assistance.

SPEECH.PARA: I am surprised that a person with Senator Teague's background can so easily and airily dismiss the importance of this scheme. In my own area of Caringbah, for example, the value of the Community Youth Support Scheme has been confirmed in a report on the operation of the Scheme in that area. The report shows that the Caringbah CYSS office serviced many hundreds of young people and found them work. In short, after a shaky start it was proving to be a success. The Budget desision to end the Scheme, to the detriment of the experiment, has come as a very rude shock to the young people in my area. What has been the response of the Federal Liberal member for the area, Don Dobie, who is on the local CYSS board? His approach was typical of that which we expect from his party and it typifies the attitude of the Treasurer and his kind. I have been informed that, when asked about the matter, he said that petitions were a joke in this place. He said it would be a farce if CYSS received any support from the Australian Labor Party. As we all know, the Labor Party has had some criticism of the Community Youth Support Scheme but, as Senator Grimes has indicated, it is nevertheless an important community-based organisation which fulfils an important and vital role.

The young people I have spoken to cannot understand the party political attitude being taken by this Government. They cannot understand the sort of cynicism that is expressed by people such as Mr Dobie, Senator Teague and the others who try to defend a Budget decision made by Executive Government. They cannot understand why this Government has decided to abolish a scheme that it set up in 1976-the scheme it used to parade as evidence of its support for the unemployed youth. Is it a monstrous trick? It is sheer vindictiveness that causes this Government to reduce total unemployment relief by over $9m. In fact, it is yet another example of what this Parliament has come to know as basic Liberal Party philosophy-to transfer funds away from programs that actually assist people, away from the public sector, into the pockets of the private sector; to disband any community based activity that provides some sort of support scheme for those unfortunately unable to find work.

Close examination of the figures shows that this is happening once again, at a direct cost to the young unemployed. CYSS has been abolished at a saving of a measly $9m. It is no accident that the same amount has been transferred to the Government's much criticised transition education program. Let us have a look at the so-called transition programs for a moment. They are schemes that the Government hopes 15 to 17-year-olds, the people served by CYSS, will move into. In short they are, of course, a farce. The States, which bear the burden of the transition schemes, reject them. Let us look at what one of the Government supporters, a party member, has said in this respect. I refer to the Victorian Minister for Education, Mr Hunt. In a letter to his Commonwealth counterpart, Mr Fife, he said that the approach of these schemes was 'unworkably restrictive, crippling and offensive in principle'. He termed the earmarking of Commonwealth Grants to the States for these schemes 'worse than blackmail; it is plain extortion'. They are not words out of the mouth of a member of the Labor Party or a young worker who is aggrieved by the situation; they are words out of the mouth of a Liberal State Minister. So much for transition to work programs. If this Government cannot even get its State colleagues to support it, what chance do the young people outside have? We might ask the same question about these schemes that CYSS workers are now asking: To what work do these people achieve transition? That is the question that has to be asked. People can be trained until kingdom come, but unless there is work for them to do it means precious little. Until this Government grasps the nettle and sets about a real job creation program through the use of public funds, any notion of transition is just a bad joke being played at the expense of the young unemployed.

The other scheme of which the Government seems to be proud is the Special Youth Employment Training Program, a scheme which it says will gain by the Budget. It is predicted that an extra 8,600 places will be created. Yet one Government spokesman is on the record as saying that 70,000 jobs will be created. God knows where he gets that figure from, or how he can possibly sustain that optimism.

In so many cases the SYETP is just an employers' rort. Companies get public money given to them to put on an extra young person at low wages for a given period. They sack those young people before the period is up and then get funds to do the same thing to other unfortunate young persons. The Australian Council of Social Service quotes a Commonwealth Employment Service officer as saying that about 70 per cent of employers sack young SYETP workers after the subsidy ends. That statement is contained in the ACOSS report at page 73. CYSS social workers have to cope regularly with young people who have been through three or four SYETP jobs, each job ending with the end of the subsidy. Yet this Government tolerates that situation and goes to the extent of providing an extra $140m to perpetuate that so-called transition program. Meanwhile, the employers rake in huge benefits. There is no check. There is no attempt to examine whether the employers are exploiting that system. As we well know, they are. In this Budget it is estimated that nearly 70 per cent of the funds for training and youth opportunities will be going to employers in the form of direct subsidies of this and other kinds. This estimate has been provided to me by the Technical and Further Education Teachers Association, which is an organisation that I suggest should know something about training if anyone does. The Government's own claims, therefore, are to be seen as hollow, even according to its own logic.

Funds to these largely inadequate schemes of training have dropped in real terms by 44 per cent since 1975-76, the year of the last Labor Budget. Unemployment has risen by 54 per cent in that time and, as I indicated earlier, in that time schemes that related to job creation or direct assistance to the unemployed have been scrapped. All that is left now are handouts to employers and big words from Government Ministers about labour market conditions. They are not acceptable to the Opposition, they are not acceptable to the unemployed, and they are certainly not acceptable to young workers in this country who want to get a job.

Around the issue of CYSS we have such a sorry tale. It is a tale of neglect, a lack of compassion, an unwillingness to provide for the real needs of the unemployed, and a real cynicism in hiving off cash to those who need it least and those who can exploit and rort the system.

The CYSS workers and the young unemployed outside this place today have demanded a number of things, as indeed does the Opposition. They ask firstly that the Government immediately refund the CYSS projects. These projects are, according to the CYSS workers and the young unemployed, according to the social workers, according to all the evidence of those involved in the problems of the disadvantaged in our community and the ACOSS organisation, the most effective and cost efficient employment preparation schemes. They ask secondly that the Federal Government take responsibility for the present economic conditions and situation, specifically relating to young people and the problems they face in relation to housing and unemployment, and provide for them in a meaningful and tangible way. They ask thirdly that the Federal Government reassess the effectiveness of present job training programs; that is, rather than pay subsidies to industry, money should be going to the public sector to be used for the purposes of job creation. They ask fourthly that the Federal Government acknowledge that CYSS is not only providing employment preparation but also is a vitally important support and referral service to the unemployed.

I do not believe these demands are unreasonable. The Labor Party does not regard these demands as unreasonable. The Opposition says that the demands ought to be seriously taken into consideration by the Government. The Opposition demands that the Government defend the action that it has taken and not put up back bench members who obviously are not aware of the full implication of the Budget documents. The Labor Party is concerned that young people are being put in a position of being alienated from our society and, whether the Government accepts it or not, young people see the withdrawal of the scheme as a callous disregard for their needs and their rights. Surely those of us who are concerned about the alienation of young people in our society today ought to be able to recognise that and suggest to the Government that the steps that it has taken in this area are, as in so many other areas of the Budget, illogical, unfair, and often acting to the disadvantage of young people in our community. The Opposition believes that it has a correct approach to the problem of CYSS. It has brought this subject forward as a matter of public importance to be properly debated in this place; not to be seen in the context of just an ordinary Budget debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, may I congratulate you on having been elected to your present office. I hope that you enjoy your time serving the Senate in that capacity.

SPEECH.PARA: Is it seriously being suggested to the Senate that a government scheme, once instituted, can never be changed or varied? Is it suggested that a scheme, once it has come into being, can never go? The Regional Employment Development Scheme mentioned by Senator Gietzelt was brought into being by a Labor government and was abandoned by a Labor government, not as suggested by Senator Gietzelt. Times have changed since the Community Youth Support Scheme was introduced in 1976. We could say that its time came and its time has gone. Prior to 1976-between June 1973 and June 1975-the number of Australians receiving unemployment benefits rose from 38,000 to 160,748; an increase of 324 per cent. Over the two-year period from August 1973 to August 1975 the total full time and part time employed labour force increased by only 58,300 people. By comparison, total employment rose by 146,300, or 2.3 per cent, in the year to July 1981. During that same period there have been strong gains in teenage employment. Total teenage employment grew by 14,100, or 2.1 per cent, in the July quarters of 1980 and 1981. Over the same period the level of teenage unemployment has fallen by 18,500, or 17 per cent.

The Commonwealth has increased substantially its commitment to the various employment and youth programs to which I wish to refer. It is all very well for Senator Gietzelt to refer to neglect and lack of comparison. The Government is putting money into places where people can obtain skills and jobs in this expanding employment situation. It is an underlying commitment to the youth of Australia that the Government is prepared to transfer from a somewhat loved and emotional scheme, as has been indicated, to something that is more practical and more worth while. As Senator Teague, mentioned there has been an increase of funds to $203m-23 per cent up on last year-in the 1981-82 Budget. In addition, about $58m is provided in the education budget for some of the transition programs. About 210,000 young people are expected to be assisted by the Government's program in 1981-82. Of that total of $203m, 77 per cent, or $156m, has been directed to apprenticeships and other training programs of direct benefit to young people.

The economy is growing, and we want young people to be able to share in the benefits that flow from this with increased employment opportunities. The most effective and practical way to help young people is to increase the funds for education, training and work experience opportunities. It is not enough just to give the support that CYSS gave in 1976, when there were such vast numbers of unemployed. Now that job vacancies are increasing it is necessary to have the skills to obtain employment. It is very important that young people are able to get into these programs. Undoubtedly, young people in some of these schemes will be employed only for the length of time their employment is subsidised because the employer is giving that contribution in return for some assistance in training somebody. I do not think it is reasonable to say that every employer who takes on a young person under that scheme is promising long term employment. He is offering a part of his skill towards training somebody so that when that person applies for a job he can say that he does have some skill. That is the significance of it. As I have said, the Government has decided that it is more appropriate to devote the available funds to these programs. I shall now deal with the CYSS program a little. When referring to CYSS-Senator Gietzelt may be pleased to know that somebody was critical of it-Mr Mick Young in his book I Want to Work said:
The scheme is no more than tokenism, confined to creating drop-in centres, providing 'cuddle therapy' rather than the jobs young people really need.
It is unlikely that Mr Young would have made that comment lightly. He went on to say-

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?
—Mr Mick Young. He went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: The $12.26 million would be better spent on genuine job creation and training programmes.

Let it not be said that the Government does not listen to the advice of those who are prepared to give it. I wish to examine briefly some of the existing schemes. The Commonwealth Rebate for Apprentice Full-time Training scheme has been increased in this Budget by $7.6m to $72m. It is expected that the increase in the number who will be assisted under this scheme will be from 78,000 in 1980-81 to 95,000 in 1981-82. This scheme was introduced in January 1977, in support of apprenticeships, to provide training for skills. A financial subsidy is given to an employer to encourage the training and employment of apprentices. It is aimed at compensating employers for the cost of releasing apprentices to undertake technical education in the basic trades and off-the-job training of up to 130 days, usually for first year apprenticeships. The subsidy, depending on the trade involved, is from $15 to $27 a day. An employer can also qualify for a 40 per cent premium on a first year technical education rebate for an apprentice who has done approved pre-training, resulting in up to six months reduction of the apprenticeship.

Reference has been made to remote areas. There is an allowance of $24 a week for first year apprentices and $10 a week for second year apprentices who are required to live away from home, to enable them to participate in one of these schemes. A lesser but not insignificant scheme of special apprentice assistance was brought into being in 1975 to help an employer retain an apprentice who was indentured to him or to engage one whose employer had had to put him off; in other words, to avoid retrenchment or to assist an apprentice who had been retrenched. The benefit of that scheme was a subsidy over a 12-month period.

The main thrust of the Government's policy in this area is in the school-to-work and work experience programs. Provision was made for 17 weeks of training, in which an employer receives $55 a week. Since February 1981 that has been extended to include two consecutive periods of 17 weeks-in other words, 34 weeks-where the subsidy is $80 a week for the first period and $55 a week for the second period to enable people to obtain work experience in a full time job. It covers Commonwealth Employment Service registrants in the 18 to 24 age group who are unemployed and have been away from full time education for eight out of 12 months. This program has been increased for this financial year and is up 67 per cent to $79.4m. It is specifically designed to increase the opportunities for further education, training and work experience for those without work who have been away from education for a period. It provides for courses in educational institutions. Allowances are paid to avoid an unemployed person being discouraged from entering a course which would improve skills and employment prospects. There are subsidies to those who will employ young unemployed and provide work experience. Some 76,000 people took part in this program in 1980-81, and in the current year the figure is expected to reach 90,000.

As has been mentioned the transition allowance of $6 a week, which is paid to young people on unemployment benefits, is an incentive, and I think Senator Teague gave the actual figures. The allowance has been available since the beginning of 1981 to enable participation in approved school to work transition courses at tertiary and further education institutions. It deals with those courses which relate to pre-apprenticeship training, pre-vocational training and pre-employment training and is available to CES registrants between 15 and 19 years of age who are unemployed and who have been away from full time education for at least four of the previous 12 months. Additionally, in the 15 to 24 age category of CES registrants, education programs for unemployed youth provide courses in literacy, numeracy, motivation and social skills. Commonwealth funding has recently been extended to cover State funding of similar courses. In the last 12 months it has been extended for some tertiary and further education courses for those between 15 and 25 years of age. About $1.5m has been allocated for that aspect of the course. It is expected that about 16,000 people will take part in this transition scheme in 1981-82 and the Budget allocation for that is $11.5m.

The Government is taking the real decisions necessary to face up to the problem of unemployed youth and to see that these people are provided with recognised course skills which will enable them to obtain employment. What CYSS provides was undoubtedly of benefit to a number of people at the time it came in and subsequently but it did not provide trade courses which offer the certificate one so often needs these days to obtain employment. That is what we must provide. Comfort is not sufficient, though on a temporary basis it may be very nice. There are 305 local CES offices providing a wide range of facilities and the Government has announced that increased counselling services will be available at the CES offices. Ten weeks notice has been given of the closure of CYSS. It has not been an overnight underhand decision as Senator Grimes would have us believe. Ten weeks notice has been given.

The capital will be handed over to approved local committees. No doubt the committees presently running these schemes will seek to have the capital handed over to them so that, to an extent, they can continue with some aspects of the work. The extent to which there has been a voluntary component in what has been going on has been stressed today and I have not the slightest doubt that those people will continue to provide services in that way. But the Government is putting the money into the job side of the situation in a way which will provide people with real employment opportunities. One truthfully cannot say that the Government does not care although it is very easy to do so. It is more difficult to make the decision which, in fact, gives somebody an opportunity to have a future that does not exist at present.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Twelve months ago the Australian Bureau of Statistics stated that 23 per cent of our young people between the ages of 17 years and 20 years were unemployed. I repeat that 12 months ago 23 per cent of that age group were unemployed. As Senator Teague pointed out, there has been some improvement in the unemployment figures in the last 12 months. But we should bear in mind that last month's unemployment figures showed a very sudden jump. There is a lot of evidence that the economy is now turning down. There is no doubt in our minds that the Budget the Government has just introduced will have the effect of pushing the economy down very rapidly. So there is still a very real youth unemployment problem. It has not gone away. It is very likely to get very much worse. The Government's decision to terminate the Community Youth Support Scheme must rank as one of the most senseless decisions taken in recent years. The scheme has operated successfully for five years and has helped tens of thousands of young Australians. Its future should not lie in execution and dismemberment but in evaluation and revision.

SPEECH.PARA: For a government so given to expensive evaluations, it is extraordinary that there is no official government evaluation of the CYSS operation. However, an evaluation was conducted by a psychologist at the Swinburne College of Technology. I wish to report on that evaluation in some detail later. The Government's decision abruptly to discontinue the Community Youth Support Scheme will mean the closure of over 250 community-based schemes and the retrenchment, as has been pointed out, of 800 youth workers with experience in counselling, training and assisting unemployed young people. There are over 25,000 regular users and a further 20,000 casual users of CYSS, most of them unemployed young people between the age of 17 years and 20 years. No other youth support program offers the type of support which CYSS offers. It gives advice and assistance in identifying job opportunities. It provides advice on basic bridging-type training, counselling referral of health matters, accommodation and other personal problems. It provides financial counselling and assistance on income security arrangements with the Commonwealth Employment Service and the Department of Social Security as well as the support drawn from contact with people in similar circumstances. This is a very important aspect of the scheme.

The CYSS program also is the only youth support program which draws substantial support from local communities and involves local citizens and organisations giving direct assistance to young people. That is very important. For these reasons I ask the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr N. A. Brown) to continue funding CYSS programs until May next year, as previously guaranteed by him, while a comprehensive public evaluation is undertaken. I also ask the Minister to consider immediately adding to the terms of reference a requirement that CYSS assist in school to work transition programs, with particular emphasis on permanent part time work in industry on a regular basis rather than the totally inadequate two to three weeks of work experience now provided.

I will illustrate that point by drawing on a practical example. In the West Heidelberg area some three years ago there was a social worker by the name of Mr Bernie Geary, who had the task of trying to motivate young people who had dropped out of society. Many of them had never worked in their lives and had no intention of working. Some of them were illiterate. They were completely demotivated. A scheme was devised with one or two large factories in West Heidelberg whereby machine places in the industry were made available to be worked on a roster basis for two hours a day. So two machine places offered work for eight people rather than two. This was a social experiment of some considerable significance because over a three-year period there was virtually not one roster time missed.

So much for the comment that young people are irresponsible and cannot be relied on. In an experiment conducted over three years not one roster time was missed. In addition it was found that the discipline of having to be at work at the rostered time for two hours a day had the effect of allowing the young people concerned to experience work in a real situation. If young people are put in a job for three weeks they know that at the end of three weeks that is the finish of it. But by working two hours on an indefinite basis they were able to see how industry operated from the inside out. They found that many of their hang-ups about having to work with people were not real. They found that they could get on with people of varying nationalities, that people were friendly and that there was comradeship on the shop floor. I put it to the Senate that CYSS is the ideal organisation to involve itself in that sort of school to work transition program. The CYSS program has been tried and found effective.

I referred a moment ago to a report from the Swinburne College of Technology in Melbourne. I showed that unemployed young people involved in CYSS projects were less likely to commit crimes than those who were not involved. The survey also indicated by implcation that if CYSS were cancelled the crime rate was likely to increase. I suggest that this is a very important finding and one that should suggest that this is a very important finding and one that should be taken note of. The report stated that the involvement of this type of group reduces anti-social feeling and boredom among young people, making them less inclined to engage in criminal and other anti-social behaviour. Keith Windschuttle recently made a very significant comment. He said:
The crucial restriction on CYSS functions is that they are not permitted to engage in job placement or job creation activities . . .

If the guidelines were revised and expanded pending evaluation and perhaps the development of a new program it would save the termination of CYSS, which will leave tens of thousands of young Australians without hope, without purpose and without direction. I appeal to the Government to reverse its decision and to renew this worthwhile program. The Budget is very tough. We have yet to see its effect on unemployment generally and youth unemployment in particular. Using unemployment as an economic tool is a crime against society. In particular it is a crime against the youth of our society.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join in this debate to draw attention to a few matters that I regard as quite important. My colleagues have already indicated that the Government has a good record in youth employment. They have illustrated that there was a strong employment growth, especially among young people, in June and July. I think that record stands as evidence of the competent management of this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: I think one of the things we must remember is that the Government has created an economic climate in which the inflation rate has come down. I note that the Australian Labor Party Administration presided over an inflation rate of something like 16.7 per cent in the financial year 1974-75. The rate dropped a bit after that probably because the Labor Government recognised that schemes such as the Regional Employment Development Scheme should be abandoned because obviously the Government was not getting value for money. Labor took action similar to that being undertaken by this Government when it realised that perhaps the money could be diverted to better use. The Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr N. A. Brown) indicated that this was the purpose of the Government's decision on the Community Youth Support Scheme. The Government has decided that more funds should be applied in other directions, for example to training schemes to enable people to be employed under the Special Youth Employment Training Program. I believe those sorts of programs ought to be strengthened. Probably many people in this chamber can point to examples of employers being able to attract people to learn a trade under the Commonwealth Rebate for Apprentice Full-time Training Scheme. I believe that scheme has been quite effective.

I think that probably more than anything else we ought to be directing our attention to problems that are restricting opportunities for young people in this country. I would like to draw attention to an important area that we should come to grips with and try to solve on a tripartite or multi-party basis, involving of course industry, the trade unions and perhaps the State governments. I refer to demarcation disputes, which I believe are creating incredible difficulties in this country. I cite the demarcation dispute in Western Australia which is preventing the export of wheat because of a difference of opinion between the Australian Workers Union and waterside workers as to who should be unloading wheat silos. I believe that these sorts of things are incredibly damaging to Australia's credibility overseas.

Other demarcation disputes are evident. In the Australian Capital Territory there is an argument between the Builders Labourers Federation and the AWU. It is hoped that that dispute will be resolved. Many people have been stood down for some seven weeks as a result of the dispute and probably they will not be able to return to work for another seven weeks. Industry will take months, if not years, to recover from such disputes, which overflow with other areas and affect trade unionists who are not part of the argument that has caused their misfortune. So I think there is a challenge to everybody in the community to try to work out a way in which these disputes can be overcome.

I suggest that perhaps some attempt should be made by the Australian Council of Trade Unions or the trades and labour councils to deal with these matters within the disputes committees of their own organisations. They should identify the roles that workmen should be performing. The trade union councils should tell employers precisely what sort of work builders labourers or AWU members should be doing. I think that such a contribution would be very helpful to the youth of Australia who are looking for jobs and have been prevented from getting them because of industrial troubles.

Industrial trouble caused by demarcation disputes was probably one of the reasons why the unemployment figures in July were not quite as good as they were in June. The Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs pointed to that in a Press statement. The statement pointed out:
The number of people unemployed and looking for full-time work in July 1981 was 9,700 below the level of July 1980. However, over the month there was an increase of 25,400.
Nevertheless the figure was the lowest July figure recorded since the monthly labour force series commenced in 1978.
The Press statement quoted the Minister as follows:
Today's figures-
That is 6 August-
indicate that there may have been a slow down in the improving trend evident in unemployment throughout the year.
Further, the Minister stated:

I am concerned that the recent wave of industrial unrest may have undermined the confidence of employers and therefore have been a factor in this slow down. It is also possible that the power blackouts in New South Wales and Victoria have affected the July figures.
The Press statement continued:
He said the estimated total of 315,100 people unemployed and looking for full-time work compared with 324,800 in July 1980 and 319,500 in July 1979.

However, the total picture over the period that my colleagues discussed is an improving one. It seems to be that industrial disputes are at the root of a lot of our trouble. I refer to a current demarcation dispute at Port Augusta between the Builders Labourers Federation again and the Federated Ironworkers Association of Australia. It seems to me that the builders labourers are involved quite frequently in demarcation disputes. Because of the prevalence of their influence in these matters I wonder whether there is something sinister in what they are all about. Another thing we have to look at of course is the constant pressures for increased wages over and above a realistic wages figure. I recall that Clyde Cameron said on one occasion when he was discussing the subject that one worker's wage increase costs another worker his job. Until we overcome the problem of industrial strife in Australia I believe our credibility as a reliable international trading partner will continue to suffer. Of course, the result of that will be that young people looking for jobs will find it more difficult to obtain them.

During the winter recess I was overseas for a few days and was able to talk to industrialists, Ministers of other governments and businessmen anxious to do more trading with Australians. One industrialist, the head of a steel corporation, said to me that he would be delighted to buy 100 per cent of his raw materials from Australia. That impressed me greatly. However, he was also very quick to say that he was not prepared to commit his corporation to purchasing any more than 50 per cent of its raw materials from Australia because of the uncertainty as to whether those goods could be delivered on time or even at all. I think it is a great pity that Australia, with its abundance of natural resources and overseas customers anxiously looking to us for a supply of these materials, cannot overcome the industrial strife causing our overseas image so much damage. I believe we have to come to grips with that.

Probably it would be a good thing if the conciliation and arbitation system and the Conciliation and Arbitration Act itself were to be totally revised, perhaps by people who know a little more about the subject than the consultants, occasionally brought in from outside, who have no knowledge of the practicalities of their suggestions in respect of what amendments ought to be made to that Act. Perhaps it would be a good thing if people with the experience of Bob Hawke and others who know a lot about dealing with these disputes or a fellow like Polites from the Australian Council of Employers Federations and others who have been actively involved in these matters were to do such a job. It seems to me that while we continue to stand by and allow all these things to wreck the job opportunities of the young people of Australia we are all clearly being negligent.

I believe it is important that the Government pursue the course it has decided on in respect of the management of the economy. I was very pleased to see the inflation rate not so long ago fall below 9 per cent. Certainly, it will be very difficult to maintain that level but I believe we all should encourage action to see that we maintain that level of inflation. That in itself gives us some opportunity to compete overses, when we are allowed to deliver our goods. I think this will mean a tremendous amount as far as providing jobs for people throughout Australia is concerned. I think the programs the Government has decided to persist with are worth while and it is a good thing that funds are being redirected from the Community Youth Support Scheme to increase the capacity of the Commonwealth Rebate for Apprentice Full-time Training scheme, the Special Youth Employment Training Program and the school-to-work transition program to be more effective. In respect of the transition allowance a total of 16,000 young people will be assisted to attend the Education Program for Unemployed Youth, pre-vocational and pre-employment courses and pre-apprenticeship courses in specific trades which result in shortened periods of indentures. This figure represents an expansion from 8,800 people assisted in 1980-81. So the figure of 16,000 represents quite a considerable increase. An additional 1,000 longer term unemployed young people will be assisted through occupationally-orientated courses. That is an increase of 500 people on the 1980-81 figure. A total of $5.65m has been allocated for programs to allow programs, other than manpower and training programs, to persist. Mr Deputy President, I move:
That the business of the day be brought on.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Chipp from moving that the Senate requests the House of Representatives to continue funding Community Youth Support Scheme programs at least until May 1982, while a comprehensive public evaluation is undertaken, particularly in view of the Government's promise to make changes which would make the service 'run smoothly and consistently'.

Mr Deputy President, I take the opportunity, as it is the first time you have been in the chair when I have risen to speak, to congratulate you on your election and to say how personally pleased my party and I are that you occupy that prestigious position.
I am very conscious of the limitations placed on me in this debate and of the fact that I can speak only to the urgency of why Standing Orders should be suspended. Standing Order 448 reads:

In cases of urgent necessity, any Standing or Sessional Order or Orders of the Senate may be suspended on Motion, duly made and seconded, without Notice: Provided that such Motion is carried by an absolute majority of the whole number of Senators.

In regard to the last point I am certain that the motion will be carried by a majority of senators because of its urgency. Why is it urgent? It is urgent because in my office there are more telegrams, messages and letters from people all over Australia on this matter than on any other single aspect of the Budget. That seems to me to make a matter of extreme urgency the fact that the Senate makes a formal request to the House of Represenatives to reconsider its decision, at least until after evaluations have been made.

The matter is urgent also because it represents the closure of over 250 community-based support schemes. It means the retrenchment of 800 to 850 youth workers with experience in counselling, training and assisting unemployed young people. It is urgent that this matter not be delayed. The House of Representatives should be informed at the earliest possible opportunity of the Senate's concern over this matter which was raised today as a matter of public importance by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Senator Grimes) and by several other speakers. It is extremely urgent also because 25,000 regular users and a further 20,000 casual users of the service, most of them unemployed and in the age range 17 years to 20 years, will as from the cancellation of this scheme be without support.

If the Senate passes the motion for suspension of Standing Orders I believe it could pass this message to the House of Representatives. What effect would that have? It would mean that every Government back bencher-particularly Liberal backbenchers-would then be under pressure from the young unemployed and youth workers in their electorates to have another think on the matter and to put pressure on the Government in the party room. I refer again to the urgency of this matter because, unless that kind of pressure on the Cabinet can be mounted urgently, the matter will be lost by default. I am aware of the concern of members of the Australian Labor Party on this matter. Honourable senators should be grateful to Senator Grimes for raising it today and pointing out what the Government's action will do to the community and to the people who are especially affected by the scheme.

Further on the matter of urgency, as I note in the motion, in early June in Adelaide the Minister is reported to have given an undertaking that people on Commonwealth-funded youth support schemes need not fear coming changes in funding and operations and to have said that an announcement would be made in a couple of months about changes in guidelines for the schemes, of which there are said to be more than 250 in Australia. The matter is urgent because there has been more than a mere change in the guidelines for the schemes, which the Minister said would continue to be funded-a fact that Senator Grimes and his colleagues of the Labor Party pointed out earlier. More than the guidelines have changed; the whole scheme has been ditched. The Australian Democrats merely want the Senate to ask the House of Representatives to hold the line on the matter, at least until it can be evaluated as promised, or virtually guaranteed, by the Minister.

I am advised that under the Standing Orders, even though no Bill is involved, the use of the term 'request' is acceptable. It is a device which the Senate may use in urgent cases. If my motion to suspend Standing Orders is passed one may assume that the substantive motion, that the message be sent, would also be passed. Such a message would then be sent to the House of Representatives. I can think of no single act that would be more effective in dealing with this urgent problem. I would not then care, next weekend, to be a Liberal back bencher attempting to answer criticisms from young unemployed and social workers in regard to his support of a Minister who had broken such a promise.

SPEECH.PARA: In cases of urgent necessity, any Standing or Sessional Order or Orders of the Senate may be suspended on Motion . . .

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-In respect of items Nos 4 and 5 relating to the reports on the external review and the internal review of the Defence Science and Technology Organisation, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the papers.

The DSTO, which is the subject of these two reports, is a very large consumer indeed of the nation's resources. The Budget allocation for the current year is some $119m, which is over half that of the provision for the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, the nation's biggest research and development organisation. About 65 per cent of the budget of the DSTO, which comprises nearly 5,000 people, is accounted for by the Defence Research Centre at Salisbury in South Australia. The Materials Research Laboratories and the Aeronautical Research Laboratories are the other main components of what is a multifunctional organisation. The organisation and the efficacy of this body is the subject of these two reports. The organisational capacity and the efficacy of the organisations have been the subject of a fiercely fought controversy within the Department of Defence, a controversy which surfaced, albeit briefly, early last month with the suppression-that became public-by the Minister for Defence (Mr Killen) of a speech that was proposed to be made to a defence seminar in Canberra by the chairman of one of the two committees, namely Dr Rees, the chairman of the independent external review. Apparently there was an endeavour to suppress publication of the report at least for a period in order to wrench the two reports, the external one and the internal one respectively, into harness so that the terms of their recommendations would go down roughly the same track. But that attempt manifestly did not succeed; we have before us two different reports which demonstrate real differences in their recommendations in a number of significant respects.

The report of the internal review, chaired by Professor Fink, the Chief Defence Scientist is, as might perhaps have been anticipated, generally softer. It claims generally that the integration of the DSTO within the Department of Defence has hitherto worked quite well and there is resisted in this report any suggestion that the DSTO ought to have more of an independent existence. It does, however, identify with some precision a number of obvious soft spots in the Organisation at the moment, especially in respect of managerial matters. It does recommend that there be conducted within the Department of Defence an efficiency review to put these matters right. The main prescription relating to organisational matters arising out of the internal review is a suggestion that the Chief Defence Scientist become a member of the Defence Force Development Committee and that the functions of that Committee be expanded to accommodate the kind of role and contribution that DSTO makes and hopefully should make to defence planning.

The external review, by contrast, which was chaired, as I said, by Dr A. L. G. Rees, formerly the chief of the CSIRO Division of Chemical Physics, is a substantially more critical document. Among the more important points, if I might succinctly mention them, made by this external review are the following: The low level of activity in nuclear weapon defence within the DSTO, which is said to give cause for concern as to Australia's state of preparedness to withstand a nuclear attack; Australia's ability to defend itself against the use of chemical and biological agents is questioned; further, the DSTO capability to engage in long-term strategic planning will, the review says, be ultimately destroyed if the pressure continues for ad hoc solutions to short term problems as being the dominant mode of the Organisation's existence. Then it is said that the amount of research conducted by the DSTO is inadequate and is less than has been claimed by the Organisation. It is said that the engineering and scientific support within the DSTO is of variable quality. It is said that some equipment, whilst of very high quality in its day, is now largely obsolete, resulting in a markedly inferior end product. Finally, in this short litany of some of the major findings, it says the DSTO is overadministered and that there is gross inefficiency in the use of resources, particularly staff resources.

The main impression which emerges from the external review is that this is an organisation of enormous significance not only to Australia's defence but also to the whole of Australia's research and development future. It is, however, an organisation which is indifferent in its achievement, of low prestige and with a very low morale. The main prescription that emerges from the external review, along with a large number of more specific recommendations, is that the Organisation should become a separate statutory authority. This recommendation, like all the other really substantial recommendations in both this report and the internal review, has been followed with a response by the Minister, replying in the other place on 19 August, by way of referring these major recommendations to the Defence Review Committee which has recently been established under the chairmanship of Mr John Utz and may or may not ever get around to making a serious report in this area.

The Australian Labor Party generally has a bias towards a departmental rather than a statutory authority mode of organisation for bodies such as this in order to maximise in particular their accountability to the government and the parliament of the day. It is that kind of bias, I suppose, which in this case would lead us to greet rather circumspectly the recommendation that it be established as a separate organisation. But we do nonetheless acknowledge the force of the theme that underlies this recommendation of the external review committee, and that is the very important theme for the DSTO of necessity to have a close relationship not only with defence research and development but also with industry generally. The DSTO is very narrowly locked into a defence role at the moment. Industry as a result is not benefiting very much at all, or very obviously, from participation in the work of DSTO, the utilisation of the products of DSTO research or any spin-off from that research. Again, it is arguable on the other side of the same coin that the quality of the defence research effort has probably not been maximised either by this separation.

As my colleague Mr Barry Jones has said on a number of occasions in debating this subject and related matters, most technical innovation in the defence area since the Second World War has in fact come about from lateral thinking by people working and thinking outside their area of immediate professonal expertise in an atmosphere of intellectual vitality. There is a very real doubt whether the DSTO, given the way in which it has been structured and the way in which it operates, is such an institution of intellectual vitality. In fact, I think the kind of comparison that one would draw in this instance is the kind that one might also make between the Australian National University on the one hand and the Royal Military College, Duntroon, on the other. Might I say that no solution to the problems of the DSTO will be adequate unless we-the Government and the country-squarely come to grips with the necessity to maximise its efficiency, not only in the context of the defence effort but also in the context of the national research and developmental effort.

A number of different organisational models suggest themselves as possible solutions to the difficulties that are being experienced by this organisation. These are organisational models other than those that are respectively supported by the internal review on the one hand and the external review on the other. For example, there may be a case for establishing alongside the existing Department of Defence a quite distinct department-perhaps it might be called the Department of Defence Science and Industry-which would incorporate the defence science function which is presently performed by DSTO. Perhaps it could undertake the procurement function of the Department of Defence and also the Australian industry participation or offset arrangements that are presently administered by the Department of Industry and Commerce, having been previously within the umbrella of the ill-fated Department of Productivity.

I do not stop now to argue these questions nor does the Opposition express at this stage any very firm view as to what the proper organisational model in this respect ought to be. We simply make the point, however, that not only should these questions be referred to the Utz committee which is presently gearing itself up to produce a major report on this and all matters related to defence organisations, but also these two very important and enormously significant reports should be properly considered by an appropriate committee of this Parliament-perhaps by the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence, or the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence or, as an alternative, the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment. Which of those bodies-or perhaps some other one-would be the most appropriate to look at these two reports carefully and report back to the Parliament is something that perhaps can be determined over the next few days and be the subject of further debate in this Parliament.

The point I wind up on in commenting on these reports is that we need a rather more rational approach to the very important problems that have been demontrated to exist by these two reports and a less reflexively defensive approach-if I might put it that way-than has been demonstrated by the Minister for Defence, Mr Killen, who in releasing these two reports commented that the external review was 'shortsighted' and 'unbalanced' in a number of significant respects and that the conclusions of some other aspects of the reports were 'ill-considered'. The reports in question, especially the external review before us, are better than this and they deserve a more careful, a more sensitive, a more thoughtful and a more constructive response than they have so far received from the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The report of the Public Inquiry into Income Tax Zone Allowances is rather disappointing.
