SPEECH.PARA: I wish briefly to allude to the history of the zone allowance. It was introduced in 1945 as part of the Government's post-war developement scheme to encourage people to live in remote areas of Australia. Two zones were established. Zone A takes in roughly half of the top of Australia, across to the Queensland border where the boundary diverges north of Cairns. Included in Zone A are Darwin, Alice Springs and Mount Isa. Zone B takes in most of the rest of Western Australia, almost all of South Australia, one third of New South Wales and the middle third of Queensland-embracing Townsville and Cairns-and most of the western third of Tasmania. No changes have been made to the boundaries since 1956. No changes have been made to the allowances since 1958. At present a taxpayer with a spouse and two school children gets these respective rebates of taxation: In Zone A, $597; in Zone B, $97. The recommendation is to increase the proportion of the allowance related to dependants from 25 per cent to 50 per cent in Zone A, and from 4 per cent to 20 per cent in Zone B. This recommendation, I should add, was accepted in last week's Budget speech.

Another recommendation of the inquiry is the creation of a special category for people living more than 250 kilometres from a town of fewer than 2,500 people. People in that category will get a rebate of $750 plus the dependants rebate for their zone. I would have thought this proposal had a lot to commend it. Towns with more than 25,000 people in Zone A would move to Zone B and such towns in Zone B would lose the allowance altogether. This would mean that Darwin and Mt Isa would move from Zone A to Zone B, and Townsville and Cairns would lose the allowance completely. The Treasurer, Mr Howard, has yet to say whether these recommendations will be adopted. It is a pity, perhaps that the committee did not consider getting away from the present system altogether.

I believe that a system of grants would serve more obvious purposes. It would, firstly, more closely account for the disadvantage of living in remote areas. Secondly, it would assist those most in need, overcoming the inequality of tax rebates which favour those on higher incomes. Thirdly, a system of allowances or grants of the kind I mentioned could be more easily controlled. It would not be open to legal challenge as the present system is, and these legal aspects are important. The constitutional validity of zone allowances seems to be doubtful, because they would seem to discriminate between States or parts of States.

This is a curious report from Australia Post. In some ways it might be regarded as a success story for the Government. To the Government, with a stated commitment to downgrading Australia's public enterprises, it must come as something of a triumph of Government policy to learn that Australia Post, one of Australia's great public enterprises, has recorded its first loss ever, its first loss since its creation in 1975. The loss for the period of this report was $12m.

In fact, Australia Post has always sought to operate at close to break-even point. Last year the Australian Postal Commission made an operating surplus of $11.7m. As the report notes, if that figure of $11.7m is taken into account, then over the two years 1979-80 and 1980-81 Australia Post did in fact break even. The unfortunate thing about that is that Australia Post cannot offset this year's loss against last year's gain because last year the Government took Australia Post's profits away from it in repayment of a loan. Australia Post had intended to continue to pay interest on that loan because, like a number of other public enterprises under attack from this Government, it has been starved of capital funds. Not only is the Government winding down the availability of credit for Government enterprises, such as Australia Post, and infrastructure programs, but here we can see it also taking money away from such instrumentalities when they are least able to afford it. This is what Australia Post said in its report about the Government forcing it to disgorge its entire operating profit for 1979-80:

The Commission had contemplated having this unappropriated surplus available to provide part of the funds required to finance expenditure on fixed assets in 1981-82 and 1982-83. The loss of these funds, together with the run down of current assets due to the operating deficit in 1980-81-which has wiped out the surplus from which the payment is deemed to be made-has reduced considerably the Commission's internal financing capability.

To add insult to injury, the Commonwealth has raised interest repayments on outstanding loans from the Commonwealth, thus starving Australia Post for capital even further. The result of all this is that Australia Post is forced to abandon substantial elements of its capital works program and/or to finance other capital programs by increasing postal charges. Australia Post has already increased its charges. Standard postage is to rise by 9 per cent. Priority paid surcharge will rise by 43 per cent. Registered publications postage rates will rise by an average of 23 per cent, imposing a burden on all those small, voluntary organisations and others who use that service. Christmas card postage rates will rise by 20 per cent this year. Private box levies, which particularly affect people in the country, will increase by 15 per cent. All these charges will go up as a result of Government policy in relation to the capital requirements of Australia Post.

The report indicates that if this process of capital squeezing of Australia Post continues then the pressures thus generated, when coupled with rising wage bills, will make further losses inevitable unless charges are further increased. The report contains a strong hint that, even on current estimates, charges may have to be raised. General postage charges may have to be increased by a further 4 per cent or registered publications charges by between 50 per cent and 80 per cent. As the Australia Post news release comments, the other effect Government policies have had is to 'reduce considerably the Commission's internal financing capability'. That means running down Australia Post's capital program, which in turn means two things. Firstly, Australia Post, like Telecom Australia and a number of other statutory authorities, redirects the profits it generates on profitable city routes towards the less profitable areas in the country. Any running down of internal financing directly prejudices country areas because the funds are simply unavailable to cross-subsidise country deliveries. In the last financial year Australia Post subsidised country services by approximately $20m. It costs, I think, in excess of $1.50 to deliver a letter in many outback towns in Australia, a service which used to be provided for 22c. That is the sort of thing to which the subsidy Australia Post has been paying out of its profits goes. People in remote areas would be wise to have regard to the effects and results which will emanate from the publication of this report. The winding down of country postal services is already in evidence.

The other danger of reduced internal financing is that programs which will cost more in the short term but which will contribute to efficiency in the long term cannot go ahead. What we are seeing here is the classic political trade-off, where something is done for short term political gain which in the long term will prejudice not only the country generally but the remote areas in particular. Capital projects which have previously been approved-presumably because the principals of efficient management so dictate-are now postponed, sometimes for a few years, sometimes indefinitely. If we look at the Budget Papers we can see that capital expenditure across the board is where this Government has saved most of its money. That is because politically it is the easiest option for the Government to take. It takes a few years before undercapitalisation of an organisation such as Australia Post becomes apparent.

What I find bizarre about this process of government is that there has been no report in respect of Australia Post such as the McKinzie report which inquired into the capital requirements of Telecom. That report was published in June last year and, despite questions by me and others, has not been released by the Federal Government. It is absolutely absurd that the public and the Parliament are not allowed to see a report which was initiated by the Government, into the capital requirements of our largest employer organisation, Telecom, which has enormous capitalisation. Why are we not allowed to see it? We are not allowed to see it because by implication, it is critical of Government financial policies. The same sort of situation applies to Australia Post.

If I might give the Senate a parallel, some decades ago, the Victorian Government tried to fool the people of that State by saving money on rolling stock for the Victorian Railways. The result is very visible today and it may well mean the end of the Victorian Government. In Victoria it is called the red rattler syndrome-referring to the Victorian Railways. That is, there is a steady process of undercapitalisation for short term political savings, resulting in long term disaster to an organisation such as the Victorian Railways. This Fraser Government has the red rattler syndrome in relation to Telecom and Australia Post. It is ushering in a new era of public administration in Australia, where public investment is shunned and private investment is imagined to be uniquely productive. This Government is bringing the red rattler syndrome to Australia Post, Telecom, and the Australian Broadcasting Commission, as well as to other public instrumentalities.

The results of the Government's actions will be to push up charges and depress the standard of service, particularly in the country. In the meantime, the Government continues to talk. Just a few months ago the Minister for Communications (Mr Sinclair), the responsible Minister-or should I say in this case the irresponsible Minister-commented on the program of decentralisation of the mail network in New South Wales. He spoke of it in glowing terms and said that the mail network should be decentralised in New South Wales. Particularly, he said:

I believe there are clear indications that it (the decentralisation program) is bringing a great improvement to the efficiency with which mail is handled and delivered, both within, and to and from the State.

That is typical of the Government-now you see it, now you don't. Two months ago Mr Sinclair was praising the process of decentralisation of mail delivery in New South Wales. The Australian Postal Commission said:

Proposed investment in fixed assets in 1981-82 has been reduced, in line with government policy to contain public sector spending, to $37 million. This is barely consistent with maintaining satisfactory progress in 1981-82 in decentralising the mail network in New South Wales.

The Government is saying that in the merry month of May it was a good thing to decentralise the postal service in New South Wales. Now that is to be jeopardised as a result of a change in Government policy, not because it is a bad investment of funds. Both Mr Sinclair and the Australian Postal Commissioners believe it to be a very good investment of funds as it will bring employment and increased business activity to the provincial centres of New South Wales. That is to be put in jeopardy because this Government's commitment to the private sector and short term political expediency is greater that its commitment to the efficient management of all sections of the Australian economy, which of course includes organisations such as Telecom and Australia Post.
