SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I have a statement made by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street) last week. I seek leave to have that statement incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
Mr President,
The Treasurer, in his Budget speech, indicated that a separate statement would be made on the 1981/82 overseas aid program.

It is important that the Government's decisions on aid be placed in the wider context of the Government's policies towards the Third World. Our policies towards the Third World take account of the three levels at which we must consider these relations-the global, regional and national levels.

At present, the most pressing global issue is the problem of reconciling the interests and established practices of the industrialised countries of the North and the demands for a greater political and economic role by the developing countries of the South. Australia does not fit either description very easily although we tend to be identified with the industrialised countries. However, this does not make the issue any less important to us. There is a particular need to consider the relevance of the issues which are involved in the North/South dialogue at a time when Australia is about to host a meeting which will bring together significant members of both groupings.

The Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting will be attended by some 40 heads of government of a range of countries at all stages of development. It will be the most important meeting yet held in Australia and one which has a wider international importance extending beyond the Commonwealth itself. This is because of the time of the meeting, its agenda and the atmosphere in which it will be conducted. At Melbourne developed and developing nations can consider the issues without being bound by the institutional groupings which so often characterise and impede progress in other forums.

The Melbourne meeting will have as a central theme and an essential part of its agenda the present state of the North/South dialogue and the question of how to move ahead. Its timing is particularly significant. It follows the Ottawa Summit of the industrialised countries and the recent meetings of Foreign Ministers in Mexico to prepare for the North/South Summit to be held there in October shortly after CHOGM. The meetings held so far in Ottawa and Mexico have established important common ground between developed and developing countries and each has represented a step forward towards a revival of the North/South dialogue. It is the Government's hope that the Melbourne meeting will make further positive progress.

Australia's interest in relations between developed and developing countries is of long standing and reflects our geographic situation and our political, strategic and economic interests. Nor should there be any doubt about the importance attached to the North/South dailogue by both the developed and developing country members of the Commonwealth. Honourable Senators will be aware that emissaries have been sent to all Commonwealth countries to find out from Heads of Government what they believe ought to be discussed at the Melbourne meeting. The emissaries have since reported back to the Government and these reports reveal there is a clear consensus on the urgency of North/South issues and the need for progress.

We believe the CHOGM should give a positive signal to the Mexico Summit. We expect it will and that the seven Commonweath heads of government who will go to Mexico will take with them a clear message and perception of how progress can be made.

Although there are doubts about how to proceed, it is apparent that there is a need for a new process of global discussions between developed and developing countries. The foundation for these discussions, the so-called global negotiations, has been laid in the United Nations. A further effort to create a favourable climate will be made at CHOGM.

The issues for the world community to consider have been refined into four headings: food and agriculture, trade flows, energy, and international financial questions, in particular the debt problems of developing countries. We expect CHOGM to focus attention on these issues and to identify practical measures and arrangements to improve the situation in each of them.

Food and Agriculture The problems of world food security are immensely complex. Too often these problems are seen only in terms of famines and crises. However, the harsh reality is the need to deal with the permanent problem through the creation of adequate global food security arrangements and elimination of persistent food shortages. The increasing gap between food demand and supply in many developing countries, especially in Africa, has been aggravated by population pressure and the progressive destruction of agricultural land by cutting down trees, over-cropping and over-grazing in the search for food and firewood.

The statistics may seem abstract, but the impact on human lives and the development process is dramatic and continuing. Some 500 million of the world's population suffer from chronic malnutrition and hundreds of millions more suffer periodic and debilitating food deficiencies brought about often by the fact that they simply do not have enough money to buy food.
Despite encouraging harvest predictions for the next 12 months the overall global situation gives no cause for optimism-

World food production declined on a per capita basis over the two previous years and world carry-over stocks of cereals are at their lowest level since 1975-76, although there is some prospect of an improvement this year.
Food aid is still running well behind targets set by FAO.

Against this sombre background, and fully aware of the vital part which agricultural and rural development must play in providing a base for economic development, Australia will increase its own efforts, and encourage those of others, including the work of the Commonwealth Secretariat and the Commonwealth Fund for Technical Co-operation. We will do this in two ways. First, through addressing the short term problem of food shortages in developing countries by the provision of food aid. Second, we will help tackle the long term problem-that of helping developing countries to meet more of their own food needs in the future. Developing countries need to encourage increased food production by their own farmers. We shall assist countries to develop and implement effective food strategies, by strengthening agricultural research, technology and training facilities; and by playing a full part in international efforts to improve global food security.

In addition we shall add our support to combating protectionism in the agricultural sector. That protectionism has severely damaged the economies of many developing countries, as well as our own by reducing their foreign exchange earnings and employment opportunities and inhibiting efficient agricultural production.
There will be increased emphasis on food security measures in this year's aid program with some $106m being provided for these activities.

Further gains in agricultural production in developing countries depend to a significant degree on advances in basis agricultural research. Australia has a proven ability to contribute in this area. We are already supporting such research both bilaterally and internationally, through our contributions to the Consultative Group on International Rice Research, for bodies such as the International Agricultural Research Institute in the Philippines. However, we have resources within Australia-in CSIRO, the Universities and State bodies which can and must be tapped to a greater extent than is now the case.

The Government has therefore decided to establish an Agricultural Research Centre in Australia concerned with the needs of developing countries. The new centre, which will be known as the Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research (ACIAR), will be established as a small statutory body responsible to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. The centre will not engage in research itself. It will be charged with contracting research work to existing Australian institutions in the field of agriculture and related disciplines for the benefit of developing countries and its principal aim will be to contribute to the solution of agricultural problems in these countries. Research work will be carried out in developing countries as appropriate. Opportunities will be sought to involve research and extension workers from developing countries. To ensure the effectiveness of the new centre, a high level of advisory council representative of the Australian, developing country and international scientific communities will be established to set the research priorities of the new centre and review the progress of research programs undertaken. In addition, the centre will be served by a small secretariat of high professional quality.

The Government has decided that a trust fund should be set up for the centre and that the initial commitment should be $25 million over four years. Expenditure during its first year is expected to be $1 million.

$2.1 million has also been set aside for food security measures intended to assist the development of secure production, marketing and distribution facilities in the food economies of some of our principal aid recipients. This assistance will be in addition to our existing country programs and will be provided by a mix of commodity aid and technical assistance, as well as support for relevant programs developed by international bodies.

Food aid also can play an important role in improving food security in low income food-deficient countries. A significant increase-from $87 million in 1980-81 to $100 million in 1981-82-has been included for the food aid program, which has an immediate impact for the poor and hungry in developing countries. There are a number of innovations in this food aid program, including: the payment of freight on an increased portion of food aid in recognition of increasing freight costs; provision of 80,000 tonnes of freight-paid grain to Africa to be provided on a bilateral basis but channelled through the World Food Program; and a contribution of at least 45,000 tonnes of the International Emergency Food Reserve which will be used to help overcome unexpected and sudden food shortages.

EnergyThe world economy generally, and non-oil developing countries in particular, have experienced considerable difficulty in adjusting to the second oil price shock of 1979-80. Overall, the oil bill as a proportion of GNP for non-oil developing countries nearly doubled. For some individual countries in this group, a substantial portion of their export earnings is needed simply to meet the cost of imported oil. This obviously restricts the economic development of these countries and, in turn, their opportunity to expand economic relations with developed countries.

The debt burden has created a critical situation for most oil importing developing countries. Even those which can borrow money in the commercial markets face serious uncertainties in planning their future.

The primary responsibility for developing energy must always rest with national governments. However, the Government recognises that international efforts need to be made to tackle the global energy problem and the particular problems of non-oil producing developing countries.

For its part Australia has been active in promoting regional initiatives designed to assist developing countries in their attempts to reduce dependence on imported oil. We fund the Commonwealth Regional Renewable Energy Resources Information Service (CRRERIS) and other activities established under the CHOGRM Energy Group. We have been active in promoting and have recently organised discussion on increased coal utilisation for ASEAN countries. Australia funded an energy planning workshop in Papua New Guinea in July for some twenty developing countries in the region and was a major contributor to the ESCAP Secretariat's study into the particular energy problems of the ESCAP region. There is, in addition, an increasing 'energy focus' in Australia's bilateral development assistance.

Urgent measures are required to assist developing countries reduce dependence on imported oil through increased oil exploration, conservation, substitution and development of alternate energy sources.

The principal issues relate to oil supply and price, conservation and the nature of financial assets exchanged for oil. These are primarily matters between OPEC countries and the major Western industrial and financial countries. However, CHOGM will provide an opportunity to consider measures to alleviate the special problems of developing countries.

We support establishment of the proposed World Bank Energy Affiliate as a fund to develop new sources of oil and to promote the use of alternative energy sources. Australia believes however that increased energy lending by the World Bank to assist developing countries reduce dependence on imported oil should not have to await establishment of the proposed Affiliate. Australia welcomes therefore the recent announcement by the World Bank that it will increase and diversify its energy lending in 1981.

The Commonwealth can take effective steps to assist developing countries in other ways. Initiatives which Australia is prepared to propose include extension throughout the Commonwealth of the types of services provided by the Commonwealth Regional Renewable Energy Resources Information Service, which collects and disseminates information throughout the region and which will also provide an advisory service for member countries. Australia would be willing to collaborate in providing advice on establishing similar services in other regions of the Commonwealth and in assisting with training personnel in energy planning.

We shall also work in international bodies to strengthen the flow of investment in oil and energy exploration and development by encouraging the participation of private enterprise, particularly in developing countries where there has been a significant falling off in such activity. Private investment can be an extremely important source of development finance. At the same time, it may not satisfy all requirements and a significant role is likely to remain for development finance from official sources.

We are also participating actively in the United Nations Conference which is presently taking place in Nairobi on New and Renewable Sources of Energy. The Minister for Industry and Commerce led the Australian delegation, pointed to Australia's own extensive experience in seeking to develop alternative energy sources and announced that Australia would allocate an additional $1 million for energy assistance following the Conference.
Trade

In the area of trade and commodities, the environment for world trade is deteriorating. The developed countries continue to face high levels of inflation and unemployment. Protectionist pressures have been mounting in major trading countries and protectionist measures are now applied to sectors which account for nearly thirty per cent of world trade.

Increased opportunities for trade, however, offer the most promising avenues for many developing countries for greater prosperity. The greatest degree of economic growth among developing countries has been achieved by those which have focused on export strategies.

For its part, Australia has taken substantial steps to improve access for an increasing range of imports from developing countries. On a per capita basis, Australia is a major importer of manufactured goods from developing countries. For example, Australia imports more textile and clothing products from developing countries than any other developed country on a per capita basis. The concessional arrangements which we offer developing countries through such arrangements as PATCRA and SPARTECA are helpful and, as the Foreign Minister found at the recent South Pacific Forum, valued highly. These agreements are complemented by actively promoting the products of developing countries in the Australia market.

The Government's recent announcement that it would call for a report within six months from the IAC on the general question of tariff protection is a practical demonstration of its willingness to have Australia's own protection arrangements carefully examined. It should be noted that this timetable is well ahead of the original schedule for the enquiry.

There is an additional national interest in seeking to make best use of our domestic resources. Some structural adjustment of our own industries may be involved. To avoid unacceptable social and economic costs, this process must be gradual.

A number of steps could be taken by the Commonwealth to improve global trading conditions and assist developing countries with their particular problems. It could call on the meeting of GATT Trade Ministers in 1982 to consider issues which have an impact on the trade of developing countries.
We would hope that the Melbourne meeting would urge a wider signature and ratification of the Common Fund and call for more pledges to its Second Account.
International Financial Questions

The debt of developing countries has grown considerably during the 1970's, even when allowance is made for inflation. To a significant degree, this increase in indebtedness has been caused by oil price rises in 1973-74 and 1979-80 and added to recently by steep rises in international interest rates.

The trends indicate that developing countries will face more serious debt management problems in the future-particularly those developing economies which are experiencing dynamic growth and therefore need capital as well as some low income countries having difficulty in paying for the rising costs of imports, especially oil.

The international financial institutions have expanded and adapted to changed economic circumstances and responded to some of the needs of developing countries. The International Monetary Fund has played an expanded role in recycling oil surpluses to developing countries and the IBRD has stepped up its activities in lending to developing countries.
There is also an urgent need for those countries themselves to adjust their national policies so as to improve their economic performance and their balance of payments situation.

On specific measures, Australia would support increased IMF capacity to assist in financing and the adjustment of large external deficits. It is important that nations act quickly to provide their contributions to the World Bank's resources. Australia supports consideration being given to a higher ratio of lending by the World Bank in relation to its capital resources.
A number of these issues will be considered at the forthcoming meeting of the Commonwealth Finance Ministers where Australia will seek to play an active and positive part.

AidThe Foreign Minister spoke of the issues facing the world community under the four headings of food and agriculture, trade flows, energy and international financial questions. Many of the practical actions which Australia has taken in these areas involve us in significant expenditures under our overseas aid program.

Overseas aid is itself an important element of the North/South dialogue. The actions of developed countries on this issue of the transfer of resources to developing countries are seen by the Third World as a measure of our commitment to the achievement of real progress in the North/South dialogue.

The world community will benefit if all its members can share the resources and conditions necessary for a decent standard of living. Hundreds of millions of people in developing countries are deprived of such basic necessities as adequate shelter, nutrition, health and education.
Of course, there is a substantial element of self-interest for Australia in promoting higher standards of living and political stability in developing countries, particularly in neighbouring ones.
As a democratic Western society in the Southern Hemisphere Australia more than most aid donors has a real and direct interest in supporting the development efforts of Third World countries.

As there is greater economic advancement in developing countries, so trading opportunities for Australia will expand. Many Australian companies already benefit from commercial opportunities flowing directly from the aid program. Often Australian expertise is a necessary requirement for the efficient use of Australian aid funds, particularly for agricultural development projects.

Aid can also serve long-term foreign policy interests. The Soviet Union has shown by its past actions that it will willingly exploit situations of poverty and hunger, but the amount of genuine development aid provided by the Soviet Union to recipient countries is small-both absolutely and in comparison with the military equipment they provide.

It is in this context that aid which offers practical assistance to development can help achieve foreign policy objectives. This is not to suggest using aid as some sort of lever or bribe in an attempt to buy short-term political advantage. Nevertheless, aid must provide a basis for mutual understanding which can only grow if donors show an appreciation of the legitimate developmental goals and aspirations of the recipient.

Mr President, this year's Budget makes provision for expenditure of $662.3 million on official development assistance in 1981-82. This represents an increase of $104 million over actual expenditure in the last financial year. Of the total amount, $663.7 million will be used for direct expenditure on aid activities by the Australia Development Assistance Bureau within the Department of Foreign Affairs, $15.4 million by the Treasury while the balance is accounted for by development-related activities undertaken by other Government Departments and instrumentalities.

The increase of over $100 million over our 1980-81 aid expenditure level is evidence of our acceptance of aid as a key element in the North-South debate. It will mean that the proportion of Australia's Gross National Product actually spent as official development assistance will rise from 0.43 per cent in 1980-81 to 0.45 per cent in 1981-82. On the basis of comparing aid with GNP, Australia is ranked in the middle of the 16 major Western aid donors, although the quality and terms of our aid are better than those of most other donors.

In addition, the aid program does involve significant expenditures and hence benefits at home. Examples include the supply of Australian grain and other foodstuffs as food aid and the purchase of a range of Australian goods and services. We intend to maintain these features of the program and indeed to look for further ways in which to develop mutually beneficial aid flows.

Paralleling the Government's decision to provide an increase in the level of the aid program, efforts to ensure that the increased funding is used in the most effective way possible will be continued. Of course, existing obligations to our near neighbours and to international organisations and development bodies account for a large portion of this amount. In fact, almost 90 per cent of the total amount will be directed to maintaining ongoing programs. There has nevertheless been considerable scope to introduce further initiatives within the program and to expand existing programs. Some of the most important of these have already been mentioned in the context of food and agriculture and energy.
Mention should also be made of the aid program's major components and to elaborate on some of the initiatives included within it. Further details are set out in Budget Paper No. 8.

Assistance to Papua New GuineaAs in previous years, Papua New Guinea will be the major single recipient, with $254 million being allocated for that country in 1981-82. this amount includes the first budget-support grant from within the new five-year PNG-Australia aid agreement announced in September 1980. The purpose of this agreement, which is of great importance to PNG, is to provide that country with a long-term framework within which to plan its future development.

The Bilateral Projects ProgramAbout $145 million has been allocated for project and technical assistance activities in a large number of countries, principally in South-East Asia and the Pacific. In both these regions, we have major long-term commitments to provide assistance. While there is a good deal of emphasis within the ASEAN program upon large scale projects, the program to the South Pacific region includes a large number of small projects and different forms of aid designed to meet the needs of thse small island states. In total, there will be about a $5 million increase in the level of bilateral aid to the South Pacific this year. In addition there will be a substantial increase to our support for regional activities in the South Pacific-these will be referred to later in this statement.

To keep pace with the changing requirements of the South Pacific new forms of aid have been introduced over recent years. One particular form of assistance which will be given increasing prominence in 1981-82 is the funding of joint ventures in the region. $1 million has been set aside to provide grants for the purchase of island equity in joint ventures with Australian companies. It is anticipated that the economies of the South Pacific countries will benefit from this income and employment creation.

TrainingSome 3,300 overseas students and trainees will be sponsored by the Australian Government in 1981-82. This is a significant increase on 1980-81 numbers and reflects the increased emphasis that recipient countries are placing on their human resources and the high level of goodwill generated by the program. Within the training program, for which $24 million has been provided, it is proposed to increase English language training opportunities and to give further emphasis to training senior administrators. Additional support will also be provided for training within developing countries.

Support for Non-Government OrganisationsThe Foreign Minister expresses his appreciation of the important work being undertaken by Australian non-government bodies. They have a special role to play in serving some of the areas of most serious need in developing countries and operating in a way, and often on a scale, more effectively than the official Government program. An expression of the Government's support is reflected in the decision to make donations tax deductible to the major bodies involved.

Assistance for these organisations will rise from $2.9 million in 1980-81 to $ 5.2 million in 1981-82. Within this amount, a new scheme known as the Australian Executive Service Overseas Program will be funded. This scheme, which makes use of the skills of the Australian Business Community, is being introduced on a trial basis in 1981-82 with the support of the Confederation of Australian Industry. A specific allocation of $400,000 is earmarked for NGO projects in the South Pacific region.
Multilateral AidTotal multilateral assistance will amount to $142 million in 1981-82; an increase of $41 million on expenditure in 1980-81.

Expenditure of $11.6 million for capital increases in the resources of the World Bank and its private sector arm, the International Finance Corporation is included in the program. A $3.6 million contribution is also provided to the Commonwealth Fund for Technical Co-operation (CFTC) to meet priority technical assistance needs of developing Commonwealth countries. This represents a substantial increase over the previous levels and reflects the confidence of the government in the CFTC as a means of assisting the development efforts of developing Commonwealth members.

Increases will be made in our pledges to the UN Development Program, UNICEF, UN Relief and Works Agency, UN High Commissioner for Refugees and UN Fund for Population Activities. The increases, which amount to approximately $4.3 million, reflect the Government's support for the special role which these bodies can play in providing development assistance at the global level. Contributions to the UN Industrial Development Fund and the UN Research Institute for Social Development will also be made for the first time in 1981-82.

Regional Co-operationAustralia is particularly keen to support regional co-operation efforts. Perhaps the leading success story in this area has been the degree of co-operation developed in the ASEAN region. Part of Australia's response has been the development of the ASEAN-Australia Economic Co-operation program. The program which is jointly funded by Australia and ASEAN was established in 1974. It supports projects and activities designed and implemented by ASEAN. A major benefit of the program has been the degree of co-operation and collaboration among research and technical personnel in the ASEAN countries. This has stimulated research and development activities, technology transfer and mutual assistance. $7.5 million has been made available for the program by Australia in 1981-82.

Similarly, within the South Pacific we are increasing our support for regional co-operation through contributions to a number of activities, including the Pacific Forum Line, seabed research and the University of the South Pacific.
Refugees and Emergency ReliefOver the last 12 months, there have been further tragic increases in the number of refugees throughout the world, including East Africa, Kampuchea and Afghanistan.

To alleviate the extreme hardships which these people face, Australia will continue to support international appeals and provide emergency aid, mainly in the form of food. One example of this is the Government's recent decision to provide significant amounts of wheat, high protein milk biscuits and sugar for Afghan refugees in Pakistan.

An amount of $8.5m has been set aside to meet our obligations to special international appeals. $2m of this amount is already committed to fulfil a commitment announced in April this year at the International Conference on Assistance to Refugees in Africa.

Aid and the Private SectorThe Government is actively promoting the involvement of the Australian private sector in the aid program. Thus some 64 projects worth $60m are now being handled by private consultants. Attempts are being made to tap the skills of Australian companies in other ways. One example, in the South Pacific, is our support of joint ventures between Australian firms and island partners.

Another response has been the introduction of a scheme specifically for ASEAN countries known as the Development Import Finance Facility. The idea of the scheme is to reduce the cost to ASEAN governments of importing capital goods and services from Australia for development purposes to match the export finance terms of other developed countries. By offering a grant to support such transactions the Australian Government aims to enable recipient countries to purchase needed capital goods and services on better terms than are available under existing concessional finance.

ConclusionMr President, it is no exaggeration to state that the relationship between the developed and developing countries is now at a crucial stage. A great deal more is at stake than economic and commercial advantage. Important political and strategic considerations are involved. It is essential that the Western democratic nations show they can respond to this situation, to the opportunities as well as problems which are posed.

The USSR has demonstrated both its unwillingness and its inability to provide the assistance which the Third World needs if the great mass of humanity is to achieve the prosperity it seeks. The USSR cannot provide the markets, capital, technology, the flexibility of adjustment which has made the West the dynamic force in international development.

The USSR may offer arms, ideology and disruption but they bring chaos not prosperity. The USSR has always stood aside from the North/South debate seeking to hide is inability to make a positive contribution behind out-dated, empty arguments about the responsibility of former colonial powers.

We in the West, the developed democracies, can show our ability to respond to a new challenge, to bring about a new period of growth and prosperity. We cannot do this by seeking to exclude the developing countries or isolate ourselves from them. Nor can we ignore them and their problems. We still have time and the opportunity to find a solution within the existing international framework. It would be misleading to suggest that any solution will be arrived at easily-without a long process of negotiation and reconciliation. The effort must be made because the alternative of economic Darwinism-of the extinction of the weakest or the survival of only the most powerful-is not acceptable nor is it in Australia's interest.

Australia, as host, has a unique opportunity at CHOGM to give the North/South dialogue a new impetus. We must make the most of that opportunity. The Government expects that all honourable senators will support this objective and that we will achieve bipartisan agreement about what has to be done.

TALK.START.PARA: — I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —A leading article in the Canberra Times of 21 August entitled 'The Politics of Caring' contains a comment about various statements which have been made by the Government in relation to foreign aid. The article says this:

SPEECH.PARA: The Prime Minister seems to believe that the people of this country do not care enough to make him put their money where his mouth has been. He may be right. On June 4 he admitted to Parliament that the cuts in foreign aid by several countries had 'sharpened the North-South debate between the wealthy and poorer countries. It is one of the matters which cast doubts on the credibility of wealthier countries, about their real intentions'. That was an honest abservation.
The leading article in the Canberra Times continues:
Of course, not all the wealthier countries have been as mean as Australia, the United States (0.27 per cent), Britain (0.34 per cent),-
This is the percentage of gross domestic product
Japan (0.32 per cent), New Zealand (0.32 per cent) and Italy (0.17 per cent).
The countries which have not been as mean include:

The Netherlands . . . 0.99 per cent, Norway 0.82 per cent, Sweden 0.76 per cent and Denmark 0.72 per cent. So, given the democratic will of an informed and interested electorate, it can be done. The rich do not have to be selfish, if they are well educated and well led.

I have made this comment in the Senate before. I made the comment the other day in the course of a debate on industrial relations when I simply said that the countries with the least number of man hours per thousand lost per annum as a result of industrial disputes are the countries of Holland, Denmark, Norway, Sweden, Austria and Switzerland. In relation to this question of capacity to give foreign aid to underdeveloped countries where the Australian record has been sad and getting worse, the countries of Norway, the Netherlands, Sweden and Denmark lead the field. They exceed the recommended level of foreign aid suggested by the United Nations. Strangely enough all those countries have social democratic governments and are very stable societies with little unemployment, little industrial trouble and a capacity for being 'well led', to which the Canberra Times article referred, to assist with foreign aid programs.

Sadly on this matter of foreign aid and the North-South dialogue the Australian Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) has been caught posturing again both on humanitarian grounds and on strategic grounds. In his speech to the University of South Carolina given on 8 July this year the Prime Minister said:

Edmund Burke said it better when he observed, in the process of cautioning Britain on its treatment of the American colonies, 'that discontent will increase with misery; and that there are critical moments in the fortunes of all states, when they who are unable to contribute to your prosperity may be strong enough to complete your ruin.' Today, all the Western countries need to heed that advice.
That is what the Prime Minister said in the comfortable halls of the University of South Carolina.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pompous nonsense.
—Senator Evans interjected 'pompous nonsense'. That is true but it is pragmatic, sensible, hard-headed pompous nonsense. The next paragraph is less so. Later the Prime Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . despite its poor overall record in providing aid to developing countries, the Soviet Union can exploit tensions in relations between the West and the Third World. Given the unprecedented military strength it has at present, the Soviet Union is likely to make a particular effort in this respect during the next few years.

I quoted from that speech because people who advocate foreign aid are sometimes regarded, in the terminology of British politicians and, I think, the terminology of the Liberal Party now, as wets-people who are not practical and hard-headed. In his University of South Carolina speech the Prime Minister was saying: 'this is tough, Wannon style November 1975, real politics'. You have to be very careful of the Russians so we ought to give more foreign aid. You have to be very careful of the words of Edmund Burke uttered years ago at the time of the colonisation of America to look after poor countries otherwise they will get after you and eat you in turn, as it were.' So at the University of South Carolina the Prime Minister was offering hard, realpolitik advice on how to deal with the commos, as he no doubt would have put it. At other times when he is discussing foreign aid, when Professor Owen Harries is writing the words for him, he puts it in different terms about the importance of aid to underdeveloped countries. I will come to that matter in a minute.

While the Prime Minister was at the University of South Carolina the permanent head of the Treasury in Australia was saying something different. In a letter to Professor Owen Harries-it is addressed to 'Dear Owen' and refers to the Prime Minister's speech on the Third World and the West-Mr John Stone, the Secretary to the Treasury, said:

At some stage, moreover, some developing countries are going to be so impolite as to ask Australia to put its policies where its mouth is. At that time, unless we can show more 'political will' than has been evident until now (for example, in regard to the dismantling of our high-protection regime) the Australian emperor--
That is the Prime Minister-
is going to appear remarkably unclothed.

That comment was elaborated on by the Secretary to the Treasury who turned out to be no slouch in the prose department. As I said, this was elaborated on to some extent in the letter which he wrote to Professor Owen Harries. So there is a yawning gap, as it were, between rhetoric in South Carolina and performance when it comes to Budgets in Australia. I think the important thing is to consider the realities of our situation here and what we have done in the past few years in relation to foreign aid. I remind the Senate that Professor Harries drew attention-I think it was a year or so ago in the report written by Professor Harries on Australia and the Third World-to the decline in Australian aid to underdeveloped countries since the Fraser Government came to power. What he pleaded for in that report on Australia and the Third World was what he called the reversal of the trend in relation to development aid under the Fraser Government-the trend which had developed since this Government came to power.

I will say something about the realities of the Australian performance in relation to the subject of aid to underdeveloped countries. One comment was made on 27 May this year by the Australian Roman Catholic bishops who urged the Federal Government at a conference on that date 'to increase overseas aid contributions by what amounts to at least $50m each year until 1985'. The report of that statement by the bishops continued:
The bishops, . . . voted unanimously for a motion calling on the Government to spend 0.7 per cent of the gross national product on overseas aid by 1985.

Those are the goals set by the Brandt Commission on economic relations between rich and poor countries. The Fraser Government committed Australia five years ago to 0.7 per cent of GNP as its desired level of foreign aid.
But the allocation has fallen from 0.56 per cent in 1974-75 to 0.46 per cent in 1976-77 and 0.43 per cent this year.

That is, for 1981. That is an interesting promise which is sometimes lost sight of in the great welter of abandoned promises of 1975 relating to wage indexation, Medibank, standards of living, the Prices Justification Tribunal and all those things which were the subject of promises by the present Fraser Government before it came to power and which, of course, have been drawn increasingly to the attention of the Australian people as the distribution of wealth in Australia changes from day to day, under this Government, in favour of the wealthier section of the community.

TALK.START.PARA: —The wealthy members like leaders of the Opposition.

—Yes, Senator Baume, like all parliamentarians-wealthy people in Australia, let us not forget-belonging I would think to the top 2 per cent of income earners. However, it is of the 98 per cent that I speak. The question of overseas aid has, in a sense, been lost sight of amid that welter of promises because there are not in Australia enough people who are personally aggrieved, except as a matter of concience, by declining development aid as compared with the numbers of people who are personally aggrieved by changes in the health insurance systems, higher taxation, lower pensions and the like. Such things personally aggrieve people in our society. A decline in our performance regarding overseas aid does not personally aggrieve people to the same extent, but the fact is that to the shame of this country that promise was broken with all the others.

SPEECH.PARA: The Brandt report on international development issues was published in February 1980, but neither the Prime Minister despite his rhetoric overseas nor the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street) made any significant public comment about it untill early this year, some 12 months later. An article by Mr John Langmore which was published in Lobby draws attention to that fact.

One might also ask what has happened to the Australian Development Assistance Bureau, which has been the subject of some discussions in the Canberra Times. In an article which appeared on 23 August the following appeared:

. . . the Budget papers show that the Government has decided on a decrease of nearly 9 per cent in the staffing of the Australian Development Assistance Bureau, the body which administers the aid program.

The average employment numbers of ADAB will fall from 481 last financial year to 439 in 1982. The heaviest cut will be in the policy, training and organisations division, which will fall from 356 to 313.

I just draw attention to the contrast between the rhetoric of the Fraser Government when the Prime Minister is overseas and its performance when he is in Australia in relation to aid for underdeveloped countries. That performance is illustrated by the cuts in the Australian Development Assistance Bureau and the actual decline in funds made available. There is an awful, yawning gulf between the heavy rhetoric of the Prime Minister overseas at the University of South Carolina and what the Government actually does. It is that matter that we want particularly to draw to the attention of the Senate and to the people of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the generally dreary Budget scene, as seen from almost every point of view, it is a pleasure for the Australian Democrats to be able to praise the Government for making a small but responsible initial effort in the matter of foreign aid. We hope that eventually Australia will reach the stage where it will hold the place that it should in the world. As one of the wealthier countries Australia should be one of the major donor nations. The effort needed to reach that stage will be a large one. We have not moved very far along that path but at least we can say that we have made a small beginning. It is said that the longest journey begins with a single step and certainly the Australian Democrats look forward to the Government increasing its foreign aid again in real terms next year. There will then be no Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting or anything of the sort and if the Government continues to increase foreign aid we will all be able to say that it is levelling and has taken a permanent step in the right direction; that the trend evident in recent years, which has been a disgrace to this country, has been reversed. I repeat, let us hope that happens and that next year Australia's effort comes closer to those of the world's more compassionate, enlightened and indeed civilised nations, which give close to one per cent of their gross domestic product in foreign aid. That proportion is virtually twice what Australia now gives.

SPEECH.PARA: This year Australia's foreign aid has increased by 18 per cent. That sounds great. However, in considering this increase one must allow for an erosion of values by double figure inflation. I think we are all agreed that that is so. It takes a lot of shine off the 18 per cent increase. Also, the rise is not particularly great. It takes us from 0.43 per cent of GDP to 0.5 per cent, which is hardly enough to make major headlines. We can contrast that with the contribution of the Netherlands which, in 1970, gave slightly less in percentage terms of its gross doemestic product than did Australia. In that year we gave 0.62 per cent and the Netherlands gave 0.61 per cent. The Netherlands now gives 0.99 per cent and Denmark, Norway and Sweden-which are civilised and enlightened countries, with prosperous socieities-are all ahead of us in that regard. Australia is now down at the lower end of the scale. It is also interesting to note that the United Kingdom gives in foreign aid 0.34 per cent of its GDP and that the United States gives 0.27 per cent.

Moreover, Australia's foreign aid includes its grants to Papua New Guinea which reflect, I suggest, a high degree of self-interest and a national obligation to a former colony. If we deduct them from the total, our foreign aid will be seen to be amongst the lowest in the world. Thus, our cause for self-congratulation is perhaps not as great as one might imagine.

Australia is in a very special situation in regard to overseas aid. I refer to our location in the world. In our region of Asia a thousand million people are suffering or deprived and confronted with the most pressing problems. I suggest that their eventual fate and degree of prosperity are linked with our own. I think particularly of Indonesia, a country which is thought to be oil rich and which has a 6 per cent growth in GDP annually, yet even Indonesia has enormous problems in regard to starvation, malnutrition, education and disease. We heard recently that certain foreign aid had been devoted to the providing of clinics for Indonesian generals who suffered from heart attacks. That may be a reasonable thing to do but it almost makes one believe that we ought to attach some strings to our aid to these countries so that it will be spent on the poorer sections and not directed to the urbanised, perhaps English-speaking, section which so many from Western countries find so easy to get on and communicate with. I believe that we tend to lose touch with the people who really need help. We must watch that very carefully.

Senator Button quoted from an editorial in the Canberra Times of 21 August which was entitled 'The politics of caring'. I, too, was delighted to see that editorial. It was an indication at least that one newspaper in Australia thought it an issue worth raising; that we should consider our attitudes, our view of the world, and indeed our reputation in the world. I hope that the honourable senator will forgive me if he has already quoted the following passage, but in any event, it is worth repeating:

The economic problems of one rich country, like Australia, are not the responsibility of other, poorer countries. They should not be expected to suffer because of Australian problems, especially when what they are given, in any case, is so tiny a part of Australia's means. But, then they have no votes for Australian politicans, and generally, their international pressure is slight just because their people are poor and their governments vulnerable.

I suggest that the Canberra Times has a point there, one that of all people we in this chamber should take into consideration. In this context, it is a stark and ugly fact that the world is spending $600 billion each year on arms. Whilst the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street) has been critical of the Soviet attitude on providing aid to lesser developed countries, it should be pointed out that, according to the figures, the Western world supplies more arms to those countries than does the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics. I am looking at figures for 1976, in which it was estimated that the USSR supplied the less developed countries with $14 billion in arms whereas the United States of America supplied them with $20 billion in arms. Of course, this does not take into account arms supplies from other Western countries such as Britain, France or the Netherlands.

The matter of foreign aid has a strong implication for our foreign policy generally. The Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) has fully supported President Reagan who, the Australian Democrats believe, is sending up the temperature in super-power relations. In doing so, for whatever reasons-I am not disputing his reasons at the moment-he is contributing to a massive and continuing diversion of resources into the arms race and away from aid which is desperately needed. The inevitable consequence is a total waste when we could be seeking to reduce tensions and free more funds for aid programs. This release of tensions is the solution the world really needs. Indeed, it represents the only possible way in which foreign aid efforts could feasibly deal with the vast problems of the world, the enormous increasing disparity between the poor and the rich nations.

The world is becoming a worse and worse place, in which life expectancy is falling and in which ancient, persistent, debilitating and eventually killing diseases such as malaria, which 20 years ago it was hoped we would eliminate, are again on the increase. The world situation is becoming worse. It is a fact that millions of people, mostly babies and young children, die every year from starvation and the diseases associated with malnutrition. These things have been said so often that, as with road accident statistics, after a while they appear to be cliches. It is tragic that this should be the case. Perhaps it makes it all the more necessary that from time to time they should be brought back into the focus of our attention. Again, I applaud the Canberra Times for its editorial. At least it has raised this issue, which it knows is not an easy one to raise as it is natural and human to want to shy away from unpalatable facts. The real tragedy is that the facts do not and will not go away.

On behalf of the Australian Democrats, I conclude my remarks on this paper by urging the Government to reconsider the effect it is having on world tensions. We do not want the Government to make dramatic changes. We do not want it to go to President Reagan and say: 'Throw away all your arms.' We are looking for something small but significant. If we do our best to strive, in our own small way as a middle power, for global attitudes that will allow less to be spent on arms we will meet the point that has been made so many times, that only very small decreases in world spending on arms will provide the means to improve vastly the lives of hundreds of millions of people and indeed will preserve life itself for millions more.
Debate (on motion by Senator Peter Baume) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN INSTITUTE OF ABORIGINAL STUDIES REPORT ON SOCIAL IMPACT OF URANIUM MINING ON NORTHERN TERRITORY ABORIGINALS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that I have received a report from the Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies on the social impact of uranium mining on Northern Territory Aboriginals for the six-month period ending 31 March 1981. I now present that report and seek leave to make a statement concerning some of the issues raised in it. At the end of the statement I shall move that the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The present report comes in seven parts and it is about twice as long as the previous report. It deals with a great range of topics, on some of which I wish to comment. First, I note that the Institute project team is continuing its wide ranging studies of the social environment in the Alligator Rivers Region. When the material relating to this environment has been collected and properly processed, it will provide a comprehensive picture of the social situation of Aboriginal society in the region. This picture will enable the responsible bodies to gauge the rate and nature of the changes that are taking place in the social environment and to take appropriate steps to confine as much as possible any adverse changes and to enhance as much as possible any positive ones. In pursuing this objective the propect team is gathering base line data on a number of topics, including the history of the Alligator Rivers Region and its people, the range of laws affecting people in the region from 1863 to the present, Aboriginal diet, Aboriginal languages used in the region, the ecology of the region, and the changing social cultural patterns in the region. The project team has also conducted population censuses in the region and compiled community profiles for Oenpelli and a number of neighbouring communities. In accordance with its commission for operating in the region, the project team has also brought to notice a number of contemporary developments in the region that are affecting the social environment of Aboriginals there. Honourable senators should be aware that, in considering and acting upon these comments by the project team, I also have the benefit of advice from officers of my own Department in the region, as well as reports from other Commonwealth and Territory departments. I also have the benefit of some first-hand observation of the situation and of my consultation with Aboriginal representatives from the region.

SPEECH.PARA: One issue that the project team raises relates to the low level of Aboriginal employment in mining and allied operations in the region. I certainly have no intention of inveigling Aboriginals into employment that they do not want; but I am interested in ensuring that employment opportunities are opened for Aboriginals to the extent that they do want jobs, and that training opportunities are available to enable them to take up the opportunities in employment. There are, in fact, moves in hand to expand both training and employment facilities for Aboriginals. The Department of Employment and Youth Affairs is already conducting training programs for Aboriginals, and that Department is to engage in a full appraisal of employment opportunities in the region. Other moves include work oriented adult education programs for Aboriginals and a training and employment program by the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service for Aboriginal rangers. But I am not satisfied that government and industry alike are unable to do more in this direction and I hope that, by the time I present the next Institute report, I will be able to detail to honourable senators further substantive progress in the fields of employment and training.

In its last report, the project team highlighted what it saw as a serious deficiency in the levels of Aboriginal involvement in the management of the Kakadu National Park. In the present report, the project team recognises that the Gagudju Association serves as a point of consultation and notes that two Aboriginal women are among the most recent intake of trainee rangers. Apart from having Aboriginals on the park staff, the ANPWS engages in consultation with interested Aboriginal bodies on management matters. Honourable senators should also note that the Northern Land Council is represented on the park advisory committee, and that the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) has sought the advice of the same Council-an all-Aboriginal body-to assist him in the selection of the prime ministerial nominee to the committee.

I now wish to turn to the subject of alcohol-related problems mentioned by the project team, as well as by other bodies whose reports I have received. It is important to give this problem adequate attention, but at the same time not to exaggerate its prevalence or effect. The project team notes:
It is quite clear that the mining operation at Nabarlek has not created this situation.

The project team also notes that the company operating at Nabarlek, Queensland Mines Ltd, polices beer sales with great vigour. These views are supported by other bodies operating in the region. The Northern Territory police, for example, noted that drink related offences were occurring prior to uranium mining commencing and that they had not increased significantly since then. Nevertheless, I am concerned at the fact, reported by the Institute, that the past six months have seen a number of traffic deaths attributable to alcohol in the region. The problem associated with alcohol consumption is being dealt with at several levels. The standing committee on the social impact-on which both government and Aboriginal bodies are represented-is looking at ways of dealing with the matter, and the Aboriginal organisations in the region are themselves taking steps to control the problem by acquiring existing outlets, with Commonwealth financial assistance, and by imposing sale and consumption restrictions at these outlets.

The Institute report refers to administrative problems that are still being faced by local Aboriginals. In part, these problems are related to the lack of administrative structures for the handling of income from the Ranger and Nabarlek projects. When I tabled the last report by the Institute, I referred to progress that had been made in this matter through the establishment of a new Aboriginal organisation, the Gagudju Association, for the express purpose of receiving, administering, and disbursing cash income from the Ranger project. This Association has proved to be of great assistance in overcoming some of the administrative problems associated with the Ranger payments. In the half year period covered by the Institute report, my Department has seconded an officer to the Gagudju Association, at its request, to assist it in its administrative and financial dealings. At the same time, work has progressed in the establishment of another organisation, tentatively called the West Arnhem Organisation, which will serve the same functions as the Gagudju Association but in relation to income from the Nabarlek project. The administrative and financial problems previously experienced by Aboriginals in the region have also been mitigated, in the period covered by the Institute report, through the upgrading of banking facilities at Oenpelli.

Honourable senators will note references in the Institute's report to what the Institute sees as an inadequate level of consultation with, and information flow to, local Aboriginals on the developments that are taking place in the region. It is my view that there can always be room for improvement in this particular aspect. I believe, however-and the project team notes-that there has already been a significant and general improvment in this field of endeavour in the period under review. Efforts are being made to consult with Aboriginals in the region and to keep them fully informed of new and forthcoming developments by a number of bodies operating in the region. Officers of my Department, who are stationed in the region, provide Aboriginals with video film and sound cassette material on these developments. My Department has also prepared and distributed to the Northern Land Council and to other interested parties, a simplified version of the legislation affecting Aboriginals in the region. The Commonwealth Department of Home Affairs and Environment has prepared and distributed its own simplified material relating to the environmental impacts of the Koongarra project and of the Jabiluka project. Similarly, explanatory material prepared especially for Aboriginals in the region has been prepared by Noranda Australia Ltd and by Pancontinental Mining Ltd.

But it is not only by publications and audio and visual facilities that we are approaching the task of consultation and information for Aboriginals. On an initiative by my Department, there have been monthly meetings of the Ranger Liaison Commission which has representation from the NLC and from Energy Resources of Australia Ltd. At the same time, the Department of the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory has re-established a Cross-cultural Communications Section with a view to improving communications between the Northern Territory Government and the local Aboriginal community. Most importantly, the Northern Land Council and local Aboriginal communities are well represented on the Standing Committee on the Social Impact, which is the main executive and co-ordinating body involving Territory and Commonwealth governments and Aboriginals in the region.
These are the main, though not all, problems referred to by the Institute. I am heartened by the overall assessment of the project team when it states:

In terms of Western perceptions, the physical impact of the two existing mining projects has been less calamitous than many people had feared. The monitoring activities of the Supervising Scientist offer assurances that there have been no contamination or other gross disturbances of the environment. And, to date, no significant disturbance to land or sites outside of mining areas has occurred.

At the same time, I note that the project team is not satisfied that enough has been done to fulfil the aim enunciated in the Ranger Enquiry Second Report, 1977, which recommended that 'There should be a deliberate and comprehensive programme to minimise adverse social effects and to assist them in coping with . . . stresses . . . and in taking advantage of any benefits accruing to them'. The report ends with the recommendation:

That all future mining and exploration be subject to appropriate Aboriginal concurrence, and that before any such approval is given, the Aborigines concerned be briefed fully as to all the implications that could possibly be foreseen.

As to the briefing, I am confident that a better than adequate amount of information on developments and their implications is already reaching the Aboriginal community concerned. And as to the concurrence, this is already embodied in legislation that governs mining activities in the Alligator Rivers Region. I move:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition welcomes the appearance of this report to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) on the Social Impact of Uranium Mining on Northern Territory Aboriginals. We recognise the initiative in having the Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies carry out this monitoring work to be very important and unique, I think, in terms of documenting social change for Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory. I welcome the Minister's statement on the report although it does seem to me that at this stage the Minister is perhaps putting too favourable an interpretation on what the report has to say.

SPEECH.PARA: On the matter of Aboriginal unemployment, as the Minister has pointed out, the report comments on the low level of Aboriginal employment in mining and allied operations and strengthens the Opposition's claim that little benefit has flowed or will flow to Aboriginal people through employment in the uranium industry. The Opposition welcomes the Minister's statement that the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs is to engage in a full appraisal of employment opportunities for Aboriginals in the region. However, the Minister's comments on inveigling Aboriginals into employment they do not wish seem somewhat misplaced. The report puts forward several hypotheses to explain the low level of Aboriginal employment such as: That mining companies have not really tried hard to employ Aboriginals; that mines represent unpleasant social situations dominated by non-Aboriginals and therefore Aboriginals avoid such situations despite financial inducement; and most importantly, that Aboriginals are unwilling to accept menial employment on their own land.

It is worth re-stating the figures from the last social impact report of the Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies which revealed that a total of only 12 Aboriginals are employed at Ranger and Nabarlek-11 in bush regeneration programs and one as an office worker. Unless the Minister and the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs in their appraisal of the situation tackle the underlying problems identified by the AIAS team the situation will not improve. The report states on page 87 that a low level of Aboriginal employment in the uranium mining industry is likely to remain 'unless there is some radical rethinking which goes beyond the provision of labouring jobs and vague training schemes'. I can only strongly endorse that recommendation.

The Minister in his speech also commented on the training and employment being provided for Aboriginals by the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service in the Kakadu National Park. The Opposition is delighted by the successful implementation of Aboriginal employment programs in the Kakadu National Park and especially by the employment of two women trainees. However, this, I must point out, is in no way a consequence of uranium mining. I find curious the Minister's comment that he hopes to be able to report further substantive progress in employment and training at the presentation of the next AIAS report because reports to date clearly indicate that there has been no substantive progress so far.

On the role of Aboriginals in executive decision making in the Kakadu National Park, the report suggested that whilst consultation on technical aspects of park management was occurring, the role of Aboriginals in making policy decisions about the park was minimal. That is a situation which is most unsatisfactory to the Opposition.

Another cause for very serious concern by the Federal Opposition is the impact of alcohol on the communities in the Kakadu region. The Minister, whilst not wishing to exaggerate the prevalence or effect of this problem, notes the report's observation that the mining operation at Nabarlek has not created the situation. That is quite true. However, the report makes clear that the quite drastic health and social problems created by the introduction of alcohol into Aboriginal communities are directly attributable to the changes mining has brought with it, such as more vehicles, improved roads, increasing numbers of business and social trips to Darwin and access to more ready cash. I must make it quite clear that I am not suggesting Aboriginals should not have these things. However, it needs to be clearly recognised that their rapid introduction by the establishment of mining in the area has greatly escalated the problem of Aboriginal alcohol abuse. Consequences during the past six months include the first three road deaths on the Oenpelli-Nabarlek road. The report indicates little, if any, progress on effective means of dealing with the problem of alcohol abuse.

TALK.START.PARA: —Be fair; they are not on their own in Australia in having that problem.

—The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs interjects that they are not on their own in having that problem. We in this chamber are well aware of that matter because we have addressed ourselves to it constantly, but we are discussing a particular report and a particular community. I simply stress that although it cannot be argued that mining causes the alcohol problem it is certainly clear to me from my reading of the report that the changes that mining brings with it certainly aggravate the alcohol problem. That is something we must face up to and take into account. On the matter of administrative structures for the handling of income from mining developments, here the Institute does have some progress to report. While problems still exist, the formation of the Gagadju Association and the provision of banking facilities at Oenpelli are reported to have greatly assisted in overcoming difficulties experienced previously in connection with Ranger. The Opposition is certainly glad to hear this and welcomes the proposal for the formation of a West Arnhem organisation to assist with the handling of income from Nabarlek.

SPEECH.PARA: On the matter of adequate consultation and information flow to Aboriginals within the Kakadu region, the Opposition notes the Institute's concern that there is inadequate consultation with local Aboriginals. However, the Minister's response raises the possibility of a situation where Aboriginals are bombarded with glossy publications, films and cassettes-some of them from mining companies-which could stress one point of view, for example, the material benefits of mining, at the expense of another point of view, that is, the social costs of mining. I stress that I have not seen the material in question and raise this point only because there did not appear to be a clear definition in the Minister's statement as to the distinction between propaganda and consultation. I think that the Institute's emphasis is on more consultation and particularly on more time spent by mining companies and bureaucrats listening to Aboriginal people-not the reverse.
On page 19 the report comments on the inadequate resources available to the Institute's project. The report states:

The resources available to the Project are very meagre in comparison with those available to the Supervising Scientist, or, for that matter, the Department of Aboriginal Affairs in the Alligator Rivers region. Yet the dimensions of the task confronting the Project are in no way less extensive. The Project must either attempt to reduce its scope or seek additional resources.

I recommend that additional resources be made available. On the matter of physical impact, I was somewhat taken aback that the Minister would stand up before the Senate this evening and say that he was heartened by the report's assessment that there had been 'no contamination or other gross disturbance of the environment'. That is from page 86 of the report. I remind the Senate and the Minister that the revelations over recent days of a leak of radioactive water from the run-off pond at the Nabarlek mine into nearby creeks have horrifying implications for the Aboriginal people who hunt on, fish and take water from these creeks. Allegations of insufficient monitoring of levels of radioactivity and of an attempted cover-up by the company involved make the situation even more disturbing. It appears that, but for the probing of the Northern Territory member for Arnhem, Mr Bob Collins, the leak which occurred in March may never have come to light.

The information raises some pertinent questions for Aboriginal people in the Kakadu region. How many other leaks may have taken place and have been concealed by those with a vested interest in uranium mining? How many future leaks are likely? What deleterious effects is this leak likely to have on the health of people in the Nabarlek region? I believe the Minister would be derelict in his duty if he did not immediately instigate an investigation into the possible effects on the health of the Aboriginal people concerned. I urge him to do so.

In conclusion I must say that we welcome the report. We welcome this monitoring function which is obviously being carried out with great competence by the Institute. We endorse the Government's decision to have this monitoring considered over a period. However, I hope that the Minister will pay some attention to the points that I have raised, particularly with regard to employment, training and the alcohol problem. The value of these reports is not only in making information available to the Senate and to Australia generally about what is happening in the Northern Territory but also in providing the data on which policies to remedy the various deficiencies can be formulated. I hope that that will in fact be the long term effect of the reports which are presented to us.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Norfolk Island Act 1979 to provide for the appointment of a Chief Judge of the Supreme Court of Norfolk Island.

Sub-section 52 (2) of the Act provides that the Supreme Court of Norfolk Island shall consist of a Judge or Judges appointed in accordance with the Act. Present appointments to the Court are Mr Justice Dunphy and Mr Justice Evatt.
