TALK.START.PARA: —I take the opportunity to speak to these money Bills. Firstly, as a fellow South Australian I offer to you, Mr President, my congratulations on your election as President of the Senate. I hope that you carry on in the same fine traditions as your predecessor who was also a fellow South Australian. Because of the shortage of time on the last day of the last session of this Parliament, I, among many other senators, was unable to take part in the valedictory speeches. I was unable to pay tribute to some of my colleagues, particularly Senator Cavanagh and Senator Bishop who were South Australian senators from my own party. I intend to take a few moments of the Senate's time to do so now. I want to place on record my deep gratitude to both these people in my own party who rose from the ranks of the workers in South Australia to be elected to the Senate and who went on to become Ministers of the Crown. They served this country and the Parliament with great distinction.

SPEECH.PARA: I well remember just 10 years ago when I first came into the Senate that Senator Cavanagh was able to teach me a very good lesson which I have not forgotten. That lesson was that one should always be prepared in this place to stand up for the rights of the underdog. I think Senator Cavanagh is on record as having done that on a great many occasions. I can also remember that as a new senator I was a little verbal, I suppose in the wrong places, and I got myself into trouble. It was Senator Cavanagh who came to my rescue. I always appreciated that. I want to place on record a fine tribute to both of these gentlemen, who are now under the title of 'Mr' in private life, for the service they rendered to the Commonwealth as Ministers and to the electorates of South Australia. I will be referring to Senator Cavanagh in some other remarks I want to make later on in my speech about a different subject.

I want to place on record also my thanks to former Senator Sir Condor Laucke. I did not have the opportunity to pass any remarks about him in the Senate but I did write to him congratulating him on his allowing dress reform in the Senate. That is something for which I had been pushing in the Senate for a great number of years. Some honourable senators who were in this place will remember that three senators-namely, Senator Keeffe, our ex-Whip Senator Poyser and I-tried to go right to the extreme in dress reform many years ago when we wore shorts into the Senate. That did not last long. Due to circumstances we did not try that again because we were afraid of what might have happened to the then incumbent of the chair. A member of our own party had been elected to the presidency and we did not want to embarrass him. However, I was able to go part of the way towards bringing about some dress reform in the Senate when former Senator Sir Condor Laucke, in his wisdom, took no objection to senators appearing in this place without the encumbrance of lassoos around their necks, namely, neckties. I have expressed to him my appreciation by way of letter and I now want to place on record that, not having to be trussed up in a necktie, I feel much more comfortable when I go out of this place at night. I do not suffer with as many headaches as I did when I used to wear a necktie in this place. I want to place on public record my gratitude to former Senator Sir Condor Laucke for allowing that to take place.

I want to place on record also my gratitude to former Senator Sir Condor Laucke in his capacity as President for always granting a person an audience if someone went to him with problems which affected the staff of this Parliament. Former Senator Sir Condor Laucke is renowned for having been a very good employer of labour in his own private business, and he carried that through to the Senate. He was aways prepared to listen to and try to put right the grievances of members of parliament, and particularly Senate staff and people employed in the dining room. I say again that I am grateful to him for always lending an ear to the problems of others. I hope that our current President, Senator Young, will be as amenable as former Senator Sir Cordon Laucke was. I was going to congratulate my colleague Senator McClelland on his election as Deputy President, but he did not remain long in the chair so I will have to leave that for another day.

The other matter to which I want to refer has received a lot of publicity in the Press in the last few days. I refer to the biography which has been written by a couple of people in Adelaide. It is a biography entitled 'Oliphant'. I would not have mentioned this matter in the Senate, but I happened to get a mention in last Thursday's Adelaide News. It appears to me as though somebody has leaked a letter written by me to Governor Oliphant. To get the matter into proper perspective I wish to quote from the Adelaide News of last week. An article by Tony Baker in the Adelaide News of Thursday, 20 August says, in part, that Cockburn and Henderson revealed that the Governor was getting advice from another source that might have angered the Government; that is, the Dunstan Labor Government in South Australia. The article went on to say:

They quote a memo from his private secretary, then Mr Dick Henderson, saying: 'The State Government's tendencies to regard Government House as a subsidiary of the Premier's Department must, I believe, be strongly resisted.

That was said in last Thursday's Adelaide News. It is attributed to Mr Dick Henderson, who was Governor Oliphant's secretary. I will now refer to the Australian of Thursday, 8 August 1974, which quotes what Mr Henderson said. The article mentions Sir Mark, so I will use that term although honourable senators will be aware that I never use titles. However, to put the matter into its proper perspective I have to quote the article correctly. The policy of the Australian Labor Party is that it does not believe in imperial titles. I never use them- Hansard knows that-unless I stress the fact when I am quoting from an article. The article states:
Some MPs also believe Sir Mark has been rebuffed by the Government in seeking a person with military background to succeed his private secretary, Mr Richard Henderson.
Mr Henderson, a former army captain, yesterday discounted suggestions that Sir Mark was having difficulties with the Premier, Mr Dunstan.

'There have been occasions when the Governor, not sure what the Government reaction would be to action he intended, has advised his ministers. On every occasion they have told him to do what he believed was best. There has been no interference at all.'

That article appeared in the Australian on 8 August 1974. It was attributed to Mr Henderson, the Governor's private secretary, and it stated that there was no interference from the Dunstan Government or its Ministers. Yet here we find Tony Baker writing an article in the Adelaide News of last Thursday in which he said that in fact there were some problems. Following on what I have just read, that article states:
Then there was the row with two Labor Senators, Mr Cavanagh, then Aboriginal Affairs Minister, and Mr McLaren.
Invited to a Queen's Birthday reception at Government House, they objected to black tie or full evening dress.
Sir Mark personally wrote back objecting to their objections. 'Courtesy and human dignity are important aspects of life,' he said in part.
In today's Advertiser at page 8 we find remarks attributed to the ex-Governor in the launching of his book yesterday. The article states:
In interviews after the launching Sir Mark agreed raising the possibility of Mr Dunstan's leaking the letters could appear to be 'mud slinging'.
I am one who agrees with that. I do not know why he raised that at all. The article further states:
'Yes, it is, but it was told to me and, like those letters, it was part of the story,' he said.
He had no idea of the source of the letter and thought it 'extremely unlikely' it could have come from one of his former staff members.

What I am interested to know is who gave the letter which I wrote to the Governor and the one which he wrote to me to Mr Cockburn to refer to in his book. To put the record straight, so that nobody in the community in Australia will be left in any doubt as to what the contents of both of those letters were, I will read them to the Senate. Many people must be wondering, having seen part of my letter to the Governor-I do not know what Senator Cavanagh wrote-appearing in last Thursday's Adelaide News. I read first the invitation which I received. It is as follows:
IN HONOUR OF THE BIRTHDAY OF HER MAJESTY THE QUEEN
His Excellency The Governor and Lady Oliphant
request the pleasure of the company of
Senator and Mrs G. T. McLaren
at a Reception
on Wednesday, 19th June, 1974, at 8.30 p.m.
Full Evening Dress, Dinner Jacket or Uniform The Answer is Requested Decorations to the Aide De Camp Carriages 10.00 p.m.
Please bring this card with you
I replied to the aide-de-camp on 27 May, just a day or two after I received that letter. I wrote:
The Aide-De-Camp,
His Excellency. The Governor,
Sir Mark Oliphant,
Government House,
North Terrace,
Adelaide, S.A. 5000
Dear Sir, Thank you for the invitation to attend the reception on Wednesday June 19th in Honour of the Birthday of Her Majesty the Queen.
As an elected representative of the average Australian Citizen, I regret that owing to the mode of dress stipulated on the invitation I will be unable to attend.
Yours sincerely,
Geoff McLaren ALP Senator for S.A.
Under date of 30 May 1974, I received the following letter:
Government House, Adelaide, South Australia 30th May, 1974.
Dear Senator McLaren,
I am surprised that you have refused our invitation to be present at the Queen's Birthday Reception because of the dress signified as appropriate for the occasion.

You will be interested to know that not a single person, other than you and Senator Cavanagh, has objected, although the list of citizens attending covers the whole spectrum of people in South Australia. Many have been invited through more than 20 local mayors. I have made a point of issuing invitations to dinners and other formal occasions to officials of the trade unions, and have found that they and their wives, like so many other ordinary citizens, are glad of an opportunity to dress up. When Prince Philip was staying here, the Secretary of the Trades and Labour Council wore a dinner jacket, and his wife a long frock. It is significant, also, that the invitations to a dinner given by the Labour Government of this State in honour of the Premier of Penang, specified that dinner jackets were to be worn.

I have endeavoured in every possible way to bring the office of Governor into closer contact with the people, in accordance with the wishes of the State Government. I have never refused to see any sane citizen who sought an interview, I have received officials of hundreds of citizen's organizations, have visited schools, homes for disadvantaged children and old people, hospitals, local councils throughout the State, St. John's Ambulance Brigades, and so on. My wife and I have received numberless debutantes at balls, have attended innumerable dinners organized by service clubs and citizen's groups, and have been present at church services of every denomination. We have made special efforts to support the Adelaide Festival of Arts, and cultural activities generally. I have spoken to more conferences and gatherings than I care to remember, refusing only those which it is impossible for me to accept. In the course of these duties, I must have welcomed at Government House over ten thousand citizens of the State, in all walks of life, and I have never found one who did not express pleasure and gratitude for having been invited here.
It is, therefore, most disappointing to be slapped in the face by two South Australian Senators.

We have ascertained that invitations to the Queen's Birthday Reception and to certain other formal occasions at Government House, Canberra, where ladies are present, specify full evening dress, i.e. white tie and tails. Moreover, your Prime Minister observes these formalities meticulously, as does the Speaker.

There are, and always will be, functions at which certain ceremonial and formal obligations are in order. I imagine that you would not wish to do away with all the formalities of the proceedings of Parliament, of the courts of law, of religious services, of the Anzac Day acts of homage to those who lost their lives in defence of their country. Nor could you abolish the rules which govern conduct in sports or on the race-course, on the roads, on sea or in the air. Courtesy and human dignity are important aspects of life.

The Australian Government has conferred on Her Majesty the title ''Queen of Australia'', and this she has accepted. She opened the last session of the Parliament of Australia. While there is a Queen (or King) of Australia, she should be accorded at least the respect given the President of the United States, U.S.S.R., or any other republic. The one occasion in the year when we pay our respect to her is at the reception at Government House in honour of her birthday. No-one who attends this or any other function dressed decently in a lounge suit or short frock has ever been discriminated against in any way, but in acknowledgement of the fact that it is a formal occasion, at which most men and women will expect to wear formal clothes, a black tie is suggested on the invitation.
Yours sincerely, Mark Oliphant Governor. Senator G. McLaren,
Parliament of Australia-The Senate,
6 Third Street,
Murray Bridge,
On 4 June 1974 I replied to the Governor in the following terms:
4/6/1974 His Excellency, The Governor,
Sir Mark Oliphant,
Government House,
North Terrace,
Adelaide, S.A. 5000
Dear Sir,

Thank you for your letter of May 30th in which you express surprise at my refusal to accept your invitation to be present at the Queens Birthday Reception because of the dress signified on the invitation.

My refusal was in no way intended as a slap in the face as you have stated, in fact since your appointment to the position of Governor of South Australia I have frequently defended the way in which you have brought your office into closer contact with the people.
I have admired the manner in which you have been outspoken on many issues, and was indeed proud to march behind you in the Moratorium in Adelaide in protest against the Vietnam war.

I would point out that I protested to the Prime Minister's Department on the occasion of the Reception in Kings Hall following the Opening of the Parliament by Her Majesty the Queen of Australia, because invited guests were required to 'Dress up'.

Whilst I agree that there are many people who are glad of the opportunity to dress up I am also painfully aware that there are many more who cannot afford the necessities of life, and it is the people in this category who are my greatest concern.

I would hope that the people who have been responsible for electing me to serve them in the Senate would not judge me as lacking in Courtesy and Human Dignity because of my refusal to be attired in either a Dinner Suit of Dress Suit when I attend public functions as their representative.

Whilst I remain an elected servant of the Australian people I will continue in my efforts to break down the antiquated barriers of protocol which were deliberately designed to perpetuate 'Colonialism'.
Yours sincerely, Geoff McLaren A.L.P. Senator for South Australia.

That was my reply to the then Governor of South Australia, Governor Oliphant. I would not have mentioned this matter in public had somebody not leaked these letters to these two characters who have written this biography entitled Oliphant. The Life and Times of Sir Mark Oliphant. I have no time for one of the authors, Cockburn. He interfered in the poultry industry in South Australia when I was very active in the industry. He wrote a few articles which did not do the industry any good. He also castigated the Dunstan Labor Government over the Salisbury affair. He is one of these people who like to stir the pot. I often wonder whether he was always right. He likes to attract an audience. Somebody has given him those letters. Mark Oliphant dropped a little remark that they might have been leaked by Don Dunstan. Then he had second thoughts about that. I think it was Cockburn who said yesterday that it was not anyone from Dunstan's office or anyone associated with Dunstan who leaked them. I certainly did not leak them, but I have made them public now.

The people can judge for themselves whether I was correct in refusing an invitation to dress up in a monkey suit and attend a reception at Government House in Adelaide. I use those words because they were the words used by the Governor, according to some of my colleagues, who had to present him with the Address-in-Reply. I think one of my colleagues was in a safari suit. The other, like myself, probably did not have a tie on, but I think he was suitably dresed for the climate we live in. I understand that they were told that if the Governor had to be attired in a monkey suit, he did not see why they should not be attired in the same sort of rig. That is the decision they took. I took my decision, and I stick by it.

As I have said, dressing up in monkey suits, claw-hammer coats and bullet-proof shirts, looking like a cockroach with a headache, and strutting around in all this finery is a hangover from the old colonial days. A lot of people in the community still like to get around done up like that. They do not represent ordinary, decent Australians. They have such large egos that I guarantee if they went to buy hats they would not be able to buy any big enough to put on top of their skulls. All they want are the fripperies and fineries. They have no concern at all for the people in need in this country. They could not care less about them. I pointed out to Governor Oliphant that that was my concern and that I sought election to the Parliament to try to do something for the ordinary person-and he referred to me also when he said that he thought ordinary people liked to dress up. I take no umbrage at that. I am an ordinary person and I have never tried to put myself forward as being anything else. I have always believed that I represent ordinary people, and I am proud to do so. If Governor Oliphant would like to advise me or one of the authors of the book as to who leaked those letters, I would be pleased to debate the matter with him.

I recall one other instance when I had to stick up for Mark Oliphant. Unfortunately, I do not have the Adelaide Advertiser with me, but I well recall many letters to the editor when Don Dunstan appointed Mark Oliphant as Governor. Many of the letters came from the blue rinse set in Adelaide, publicly stating that, because of the character of Mark Oliphant and his outspokenness, they would not accept invitations to garden parties at Government House. That is what they thought of him. On many occasions I stood up in public and defended him because I thought at least he brought something to the office and would earn his keep. I have always said, and I still believe, that the position of Governor of a State is an unnecessary financial burden on the taxpayer and that the sooner it is done away with the better. We could get back to using people such as the Chief Secretary, who could easily do the job the Governor does.

I think I have managed to get off my chest my concern that some person, for a bit of cheap publicity, saw fit to leak a confidential letter between myself and the Governor of South Australia, probably to sell a few more issues of the book. I am very pleased that I have been able to take the opportunity to let the general public know the full contents of the correspondence between myself and Governor Oliphant. Members of the public will have no doubts about what was in the correspondence. They can read it in Hansard. If the Press picks up the matter and reports it, the public can read about it in full tomorrow. Those are the types of tricks that some authors use to sell books and get some cheap publicity. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Finniss River and Rum Jungle Regions

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 3 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the current environmental condition of the Finniss River and Rum Jungle regions.
(2) Have any programs been embarked upon to rehabilitate the polluted 100 kilometres stretch of the Finniss River, if so, what are they and if not, why not.
(3) What are the detailed cost estimates for each program considered, including the adopted program.
(4) What compensation has been provided to the Aboriginal community who were forced to vacate the land.
(5) What form of guarantee can be given to Arnhem Land Aborigines that a repetition will not occur at Ranger, Nabarlek, Koongarra or Jabiluka mine sites.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question.

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The environmental condition of the Finniss River and Rum Jungle regions is detailed in a report prepared by the Australian Atomic Energy Commission (AAEC) in September 1975 (Report AAEC/E365: Rum Jungle Environmental Studies). This report was based on extensive environmental studies undertaken by the AAEC and the then Department of the Northern Territory in the period 1973-1975. I understand that current environmental conditions remain as described in that report.

(2) and (3) I am advised that the Commonwealth Government provided in the 1980-81 Budget $200,000 to enable work to commence on a rehabilitation program for the Rum Jungle area including $140,000 for detailed site investigations.

Following an approach by the Chief Minister, Northern Territory, to the Prime Minister, the Commonwealth Government accepted in principle that the Territory should take responsibility for conducting the work. The Northern Territory Government has established an internal working party which is to prepare a report for that Government so that the Commonwealth can be advised of the standards to which rehabilitation is to be undertaken, the measures which are to be adopted, firm estimated costs and the time frame for undertaking the program. Commonwealth Department and Australian Atomic Energy Commission officers are providing information to the working party. Upon receipt of the report, the Commonwealth will then be in a position to consider the question of the level of funding.

(4) I am advised that there were no Aboriginal groups living in the area taken up by the Rum Jungle operation immediately before the operation commenced, that forced evacuation did not take place and compensation was not an issue.

(5) The Second Report of the Ranger Uranium Environmental Inquiry made recommendations which dealt directly with the impact of the Ranger operation on the regional environment, including the drainage system likely to be affected by mining operations. These recommendations were accepted by the Government. 'Environmental Requirements for the Ranger Project' derived from the above recommendations have been included in Northern Territory legislation, in the mining authority and in the agreement between the Commonwealth and the Northern Land Council under which mining operations on the Ranger project are proceeding. A similar set of 'Environmental Requirements' apply to the Nabarlek Project.

No decision has yet been taken on the development of either the Koongarra or the Jabiluka deposits. Development approval for these projects would be considered by the Government only after the satisfactory completion of the necessary environmental procedures, compliance with the Government's foreign investment guidelines and the conclusion of satisfactory arrangements with the Aboriginal people.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Department of Home Affairs and Environment

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 14 May 1981 (Hansard, page 1968) Senator McIntosh asked the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Is it a fact that a considerable part of the work of the environmental division of the Department of Home Affairs and Environment has been devoted, firstly, to assessing environmental impact statements for proposed uranium mines such as Jabiluka and, secondly, to provide Commonwealth leadership in setting up codes of practice for the uranium industry Australia-wide? Is the division to be reduced in size as a result of the razor gang decision to let the States control nuclear activities? Does the Minister agree on the need for an expert national body, analogous to the National Health and Medical Research Council, which could set nuclear standards?
The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The work of those parts of the Environment Division of the Department of Home Affairs and Environment which are concerned with the assessment of environmental impact statements and the development of uniform codes of practice will not be reduced as a consequence of the Government's decision that responsibility for the regulation and control of nuclear activities in Australia will be implemented as far as possible by the States and the Northern Territory, with the Commonwealth maintaining a co-ordinating role. This decision confirms the Government's policy that implementation of codes of practice should in general be the responsibility of State and Northern Territory governments. The Commonwealth Government will continue to assess environmentally significant uranium mining proposals for which Commonwealth decisions are required under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act and to develop codes of practice under the Environment Protection (Nuclear Codes) Act in close consultation with the States and the Northern Territory.

In the case of uranium mining operations in the Alligator Rivers Region, the Supervising Scientist continues to carry out his functions as laid down in the Environment Protection (Alligator Rivers Region) Act, including 'to devise and develop, and to promote and assist in the devising and development of . . . standards, practices and procedures in relation to uranium mining operations in the region for the protection of, or in so far as those standards practices and procedures affect, the environment in the region . . .'.

The implementation of radiation protection standards in Australia is the responsibility of Commonwealth, State and Northern Territory Governments. The Radiation Health Committee of the National Health and Medical Research Council (NH and MRC) recommends radiation protection standards in relation to human health aspects of radiation protection. This committee includes representatives from relevant Commonwealth, State and Northern Territory bodies. Nuclear codes of practice, developed under the Environment Protection (Nuclear Codes) Act on a co-operative basis by Commonwealth and State Governments, take into account the NH and MRC recommendations on radiation protection standards wherever appropriate.

Since expert advice on radiation protection standards is already available to Government through the Radiation Health Committee there is no requirement to establish a new body for the setting of such standards.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 29 May 1981 (Hansard, page 2338) Senator Watson asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for the Capital Territory a question, without notice, seeking information regarding firearms legislation in the Australian Capital Territory.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for the Capital Territory has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question.

Honourable senators will be aware that the Federal Government is only directly concerned with firearms control legislation in the Australian Capital Territory. The existing legislation controlling firearms in the Australian Capital Territory, the Gun Licence Ordinance 1937, was last amended in 1979. New legislation is proposed which will cover both firearms and certain other dangerous weapons and which will tighten controls considerably. Details of the legislation are still under discussion between officers of the Department of the Capital Territory and the Australian Federal Police. However, it is envisaged that the possession of firearms will be restricted to licensed persons, that all firearms will be required to be registered and that restrictions, beyond those in the existing legislation, will apply to the use of firearms in the Territory.
